TALK.START.PARA: —The statement on higher education which has not been read here in the Senate is an important one and represents a refreshing change since the appointment of Mr Dawkins in the other place as Minister for Employment, Education and Training. It repudiates the failure of the Hawke Labor Government over the last four years and it is no wonder that the Minister representing that Minister, Senator Ryan, did not read that speech here but had it incorporated in Hansard. Despite its refreshing aspects, it represents, first, a delay of decision by the present Government to act upon the long agenda of necessary items in higher education. Through the setting up of an interdepartmental inquiry within the Minister's own Department, it has put off higher education measures by 12 months when we already know the situation in this country in higher education institutions and what needs to be done. Secondly, it represents an intrusive government approach to the important matters on that agenda and not the freer approach of the Opposition to allow institutions, universities and colleges to determine their own destiny on the guidelines that we would propose.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, it represents yet another step in the introduction of tertiary tuition fees by a Labor government. During the last Parliament, Senator Ryan announced the introduction of the higher education administration charge. It was a direct repudiation of the Labor Party's undertakings not to introduce tertiary tuition fees. Of course, in the statement we see that that $250 fee has been increased to $263 and has been made more onerous upon students. I will come back to that briefly later. This second step, which directly announces the reintroduction of tuition fees for postgraduate students, is tucked away on the fifteenth page of a 16-page statement. There is no reference in the Budget Papers, in any Press release or in any other public disclosure to this second major repudiation by the Labor Government of its policy not to reintroduce tertiary fees. I will highlight that matter in a few minutes.

Finally, the matters of substance in this statement are yet another illustration of the Hawke Labor Government responding positively to the published policies of the Opposition. Before the last election a most careful, well thought through, comprehensive document on higher education policy was put forward by the Opposition. On the basis of that policy the present Minister, Mr Dawkins, has put forth this statement, not on the basis of his own Party platform or on the basis of the complete vacuum of statements that had been put by his own Party before the election.

Let me deal briefly with the four aspects of my own evaluation of the Minister's statement. First, the statement is an unnecessary delay of 12 months to put off the decisions that we ought to be seeing the Minister make right now. It is a delay because he wants to distance himself from the failure of his predecessor of the last 4 1/2 years. Year by year the Opposition has criticised the Government for the ineffective growth in higher education places in our universities and colleges. We have said that given the restrictions upon public finance in the Government's Budget, we can see only a small increase from year to year in new places in universities and colleges. This year, true to our assessment, only 5,800 student places are added to the number of places already existing in our universities and colleges. Yet in the Minister's statement that is now before the Parliament the Minister admits that this year there is a net unmet demand of 13,000 to 20,000-that is, those who have been turned away from our universities. This is estimated by the end of the century to be as much as 75,000. All those families in Australia who find that their teenage school leaver sons and daughters are not finding the ability to enrol in a university or college need to face up to the criticism that we have levelled every year at the Hawke Labor Government, that there needs to be a freeing up of institutions so that they can put to work additional private resources to meet the unmet demand.

Represented in the statement is a lame apology for the small increment in places of 5,800. The Government is providing additional money for only 3,500 to 4,000 of those places. It is a tiny increase of one per cent in enrolments, and by no means will meet the more than 20,000 net would-be enrollees who will be turned away next year from universities and colleges. The Minister wants to face up to that failure not overnight, not directly, frankly and honestly, but by allowing a 12 months delay to put some distance between himself and his predecessor.

Secondly, the delay arises from the way in which this statement in setting goals for the Government is directly responding to Liberal Party of Australia policy. Again, it would be some embarrassment for Mr Dawkins to admit honestly that the main substance of his statement is a direct response to our policy, with the pragmatic Hawke Government yet again borrowing the tried and tested policies of the Opposition. The Minister wants a 12-month buffer in which he can slide into accepting the strengths of the Opposition's policy rather than have a complete turnabout overnight.

Also, the reason for this delay is to put some distance between the Minister's own record as the shadow Minister for Education immediately prior to the Hawke Labor Government's election in 1983. We in this chamber remember that in 1982 Mr Dawkins was the shadow Minister for Education, and Mr Hayden sacked him from that job because he had alienated his constituency-the education representatives, not least the independent schools. Mr Hurford was put in to try to patch it up and to try to win back some approval from those whom Mr Dawkins had alienated. Let me remind the Senate of some of the things Mr Dawkins said in 1982 when he was shadow Minister, particularly on the matters to which he has now referred in his statement to the Parliament. Is this the Mr Dawkins who said when he was shadow Minister that the reintroduction of fees was `educationally unsound and economic idiocy'. That is what he said in the Press release of 30 June 1981. He also said that support for fees could be found only among `the back room and back bench ideologues of the Liberal Party'. On another occasion he described fees as `short-sighted folly'. Does Mr Dawkins wish to apply that statement to his own Government? He also wants time to percolate a change within the Australian Labor Party. The Minister wants time to move because he sees that the plateau that I have described every month over the last several years in the Senate chamber-the situation that we in Australia are locked into until we free up private resources-needs to be changed. We have to get off the plateau by overcoming this ideological barrier to appropriate supplementary resources coming from private sources. There is explicit reference to this matter in the statement, which I regard as pragmatic in the Hawke tradition. I know Senator Robert Ray would welcome the betterment of higher education in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In saying that these measures are all a delay, I remind the Senate very briefly of the reports and the information we already have. There is the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission review of efficiency and effectiveness in higher education. That review was extensive, and it has been with us for months. What is the Government doing in response to it? It is having another inquiry. There was a favourable reference to that review in the Minister's statement. It was described as a good starting point or a basis that will be useful. But instead of making decisions on the basis of that review, the Government is putting off the matter for 12 months. May I be a little self-indulgent and mention the tenure inquiry. I happened to initiate and chair a Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts inquiry into tenure and this Government, in five years, has not yet responded to the excellent set of recommendations that have been well received and acted upon by many higher education institutions. But the Government has not directly responded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I believe these arguments are of such import that we should have more Government senators in the chamber to listen to them, particularly the representative of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I draw your attention to the state of the Senate.
—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that all that is necessary is to call attention to the absence of a quorum. There is no requirement for a speech.

—We already have the reports of the efficiency and effectiveness review and the Senate tenure inquiry, and we have the institutions' own submissions for the coming triennium. They have all been received by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. They relate not only to 1988 but also to 1989 and 1990. All this information is fully available. The Government, instead of making decisions on these matters, wants a 12-month delay for political reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer also to the higher education policy of the Liberal Party. It is clear and has been published and even Senator Button, who is at the table, will have read it carefully and encouraged his colleague Mr Dawkins to respond to it. There are also international comparisons. We have known for years that Australia is falling short compared with Japan, the United States of America and West Germany. Yet again trotted out in the Minister's statement is the finding that Australia is inadequate. Instead of decisions being made to do something about the matter, it is just put off to another internal, interdepartmental committee inquiry.

Similarly, the reports on unmet demand are well known. In May last year and May this year the Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Principals Committee published a tragic increase in unmet demand. We know that we have these problems, we know what we need to do about them, so why should we have this delay?

The Government's approach is to be intrusive. It is the approach of a Big Brother government, distinctively different from the approach that the Liberal Party has advocated and continues to advocate; that is, to give guidelines and national goals to our institutions and to give them the real resources with which to prosecute those goals and to allow them the flexibility to make their own decisions, and to heighten their freedom and their autonomy. This statement, in great contrast, represents the Government being more intrusive upon those institutions. For instance, on page 9 we read:

We need to address such issues directly and deliberately, where necessary using funding arrangements as a primary level for reform. The Government will provide leadership and national direction in this process.

That is a set of euphemisms for a Big Brother approach, for increased government intrusion. Similarly, page 10 states that the announced policy discussion paper is to be commissioned entirely within the portfolio of the Minister. The Secretary to his Department will establish a task force, and there is only a halting reference to some participation-perhaps just one person; maybe not the Chairman-by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. Then we have this lame statement:
Consultations will be held with outside bodies as appropriate.

I impress upon the Minister-I do not wish to warn him-that the Opposition will be watching most carefully over the next six to nine months to see that consultation takes place not only with institutions but with every person and group in Australia that has a right to react to and respond to the statement that has been put down here today.

The statement about fees is remarkable. I need to quote two paragraphs from page 15 in this regard. This will horrify all the Labor Party branches and all the students around Australia who thought that they could let the Labor Party off scot-free in the last election, and just demonstrate, I think quite wrongly, against the Liberal Party's approach of bringing supplementary private resources to higher education. The two paragraphs on page 15 of the Minister's statement read:

In addition, we have taken some early steps in the process of reform. Research funding will be less the exclusive province of the universities, and some existing research funding will be redirected through targeted schemes. The Government will also relax the prohibition on fees for a limited range of postgraduate courses involving professional upgrading for people already in employment, as for example in the case of specialised postgraduate courses for medical practitioners.

This latter measure responds to requests made by a number of institutions which wish to expand their course offerings and revenue base. Fees will be charged at the discretion of individual institutions, subject to my approval, and the Commonwealth will not reduce the level of its general funding for institutions on account of revenue generated by fees.

If the higher education administration charge in the last Parliament by the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan), despite Australian Labor Party policy, was the first step towards the reintroduction of tertiary fees, Mr Dawkins's decision is the second step. It will provide for fees for postgraduate students. Clearly, the Opposition welcomes the flexibility and honest accountability associated with the supplementary resources which would be raised. I know from my consultations with vice-chancellors and principals that they welcome being able to initiate new activity, but the hypocrisy which this move demonstrates must be understood by the Government and the Labor Party.

The statement represents a response to the positive policies put forward before the election by the Liberal Party of Australia. In enormous contrast to what happened during the last two Parliaments, when we did not hear any of these statements from Senator Ryan and the Labor Government, Mr Dawkins now, refreshingly, talks about the need for a change of attitude, processes and structures. He calls for increased priority for teaching and research related to Australia's direct development needs and for increased teaching and research priority in technology.

Only a few years ago I put it to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) that there was an outcry among Labor Party supporters at the idea that there would be even a linking of education to employment need. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has started to change that approach in his Party and I welcome that move after all these years. The change is represented in Mr Dawkins's refreshing approach. He says, `Let us ensure that this country's education resources are used to achieve goals of priority for everyone in the community, not some indulgent scholastic activities which have no direct relevance to Australia's development needs, employment and technological resources.'

Government senators have been hearing this type of statement only from us in recent years, and increasingly from Senator Button; and now we have heard it from another Minister, Mr Dawkins. We welcome the references on pages 11, 12 and 13 to growth, productivity and efficiency; yet when Opposition senators advocated those aims in recent years, Senator Ryan would parody us and on the Government's behalf criticise us for treating education too much like an industry or something in the market-place. I reject that parody. At last there is a Labor education Minister who is responding to what the Liberal Party has urged as being in Australia's best interests.

I note the healthy, sensible references in the statement to the ending of the binary system, whereby colleges of advanced education were seen as second-class and separate from universities. Involved with that reassessment is a reassessment of the research element in the salaries of every university staff member. The Australian Research Council is to review the full resource in salary form of research in universities and make sure that it goes wherever the centres of excellence are, whether in one part of the former binary system or another.

I have already referred to tenure and to the call in the statement by the Minister for flexibility, incentive and performance. These were exactly the criteria that determined our recommendations in the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts inquiry of which Senator Robert Ray, who is sitting opposite, and I were members some years ago. The freeing up of private resources and employing them in our higher education institutions will be important. Similarly, there is a place for appropriate private institutions. Here we have a healthy departure, in the Minister's acceptance of private institutions, from previous policy. It is in great contrast to Senator Ryan's knee-jerk response in rejecting, for instance, the Bond University on the Gold Coast in Queensland.

I welcome the references to collaboration with industry, the importance of management, particularly at middle levels in our institutions, and the importance of bringing up to date in practice the relationship that higher education institutions should have with the Commonwealth as against the States. I also welcome the reference to post-graduate education, teacher education resources, particularly in maths and science, and the need to clarify and make more flexible and useful the relationship between higher education institutions and technical and further education. These sensible initiatives which, unfortunately, are compromised by the Minister's delay of 12 months, are long overdue for action in developing our higher education institutions.

I urge the Minister to involve members of the Opposition in the Parliament in the review that is to proceed over the next nine months; not just to consult where he may, in a limited way, think is appropriate but to consult with all the interests around Australia to ensure that the good goals that are mostly set out in this statement can be achieved. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ministerial statement put down in the other place earlier today, and incorporated in Hansard by the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, on behalf of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, entitled `The Challenge for Higher Education in Australia' is a rather curious document. It goes through and rehearses a number of the criticisms that have been made over time of the education system in Australia and seemingly accepts those criticisms that have been made in this place in education debates over the past four or five years. It seems to suggest that, yes, those criticisms have validity and that the Government is now about to have an inquiry to find out what it needs to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats support the Government's belated recognition of the important role of higher education in the economic development of this country. Honourable senators who have engaged in those previous debates will remember that over a long time-in fact since I came here in 1981-I have raised time and again the importance of funding higher education institutions. I have used as an argument, but as only one of the arguments, the enormous return that the country receives from its higher education institutions. On behalf of the Democrats I campaigned very strongly on this during the last election and criticised both the Government's record and the Opposition's rather odd policies, which I think would have only compounded the problem and not solved it. However, there must be a concern that the Government is seeking to direct higher education excessively into a particular dimension of activity while neglecting the obvious and important role that education has across the board.

A very interesting article by a member of the World Bank research staff entitled `Links Between Education and the Labour Market: a broader perspective' in the European Journal of Education towards the end of last year made some very pertinent points with regard to this attempt. After summarising a range of measures that have been carried out in a whole series of countries, the conclusion was:
. . . state intervention in education may in fact do a disservice to achieving a better link between education and the labour market.
(Quorum formed)
It also stated:
The dismal account of failed policies may give the impression that achieving a close link between education and the labour market is like searching for the Holy Grail.

The article goes on to detail some of the reasons why it is very difficult to achieve that link-which is the only major new item in the statement. Firstly, there is the simple lack of an empirical base linking education and the labour market. Secondly, governments are heavily involved in the financing and regulation of education. Thirdly, and very importantly, there is the political cost of adopting a policy conducive to long term social welfare, even if it is unpopular by present day demands.

The Government wants a new catch-cry. It is probably relatively superficial. One hopes that in the ensuing inquiry it will be fleshed out and more attention will be given to the abundant amount of research which is available. The direction of research and teaching to short term goals to the detriment of other socially desirable and useful work which higher education institutions do is not the only problem we are likely to encounter if the Government lurches from its present position to a wholehearted embrace of the economic benefits of education. It is unfortunate that these Government moves do not tend to occur smoothly but rather in a lurching fashion. It rushes right across the spectrum, leaving all the intermediate points floundering.

As was announced prior to the statement, the Government wishes to aggregate the various small research schemes into one larger Australian Research Council. This is something that I, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, have advocated for quite a long time.

However, in doing so the Democrats have raised a series of safeguards which we believe ought to be incorporated into the Australian Research Council. We hope that the Government, in moving in this way, will incorporate those safeguards. It is very important who serves on the Research Council. There are a variety of ways in which one can allocate research. The best way is to try to get an adequate mix of those who are looking at the longer term needs of the community and those who are acutely aware of the current research taking place in any field.

Professor Hanbury Brown, in a book called The Wisdom of Science, makes a pertinent point when he refers to the difficulty of funding research and what is likely to happen if we get it wrong. On page 117 of his book he says:

Paradoxically, the popular, often self-righteous and apparently innocuous demand that all research should be relevant to our social needs is one of the greatest dangers to the advance of science, and to the long-term satisfaction of these needs. To insist on relevance in basic research is rather like insisting on naturalism in art; if you are successful you end up with something not radically new, but comfortingly familiar . . .

To whom can we entrust the disbursement of money for basic research? As we have already seen the choice of what research we should support involves, amongst other questions, a judgment of what is most likely to advance the frontiers of science. That is inescapably a scientific matter and must be done largely by scientists. If we give the job to a group of non-scientists they will, especially if they are elderly, probably give most of the available funds to medical research which, like missionary work in the past, they will think of as being as good as beyond reproach.

(Quorum formed) The professor raises a very interesting and pertinent example when he points out that cancer research in the United States has been done largely by pouring vast amounts of money into medical research, whereas the major advances in cancer research may, and probably will, take place in molecular physics-a branch of science apparently remote from medicine-and that the advance of molecular physics will depend on other branches of science, such as mathematics and computing. Whilst one might want to talk about relevance, it is often difficult to know what is precisely relevant to the item in question. By ruling out a priori certain areas as not being relevant, one is likely to stunt rather than to advance the operations of science and scientific research. These views conflict very much with the values which are expressed in the first part of the statement by Minister Dawkins, made in the other place earlier today.

The second major part of the ministerial statement is devoted to a discussion of the types of items the Government intends to look at and on which it intends to put out a policy discussion paper towards the end of this year. Unfortunately, the inquiry is to be a departmental inquiry-a rather extraordinary proposal considering the extent of the operation that is concerned. (Quorum formed)

I thought I was trying to go rather dispassionately through this, but it seems to have raised the ire of somebody. The point I was referring to, which is mentioned in the second part of the paper, states that the Government is looking at a departmental inquiry into the very wide-ranging operation of the tertiary education system in Australia. I think it is wrong in principle and in practice that such a far-reaching inquiry, upon which the Government will make an evident determination of its position, should be conducted behind closed doors by the Department of Employment, Education and Training without the benefit of input from the public and from those sectors and groupings within the community such as fellows, college academics, vice-chancellors committees amongst others, and the directors and principals of higher education; they should be allowed ready access to all of the points that have been raised in this inquiry.

I would like to look at the propositions that the inquiry will address. It will address the desirable rates of growth in higher education and the resources required to achieve this growth. I think that to suggest in 1987 that we need an inquiry to look at that item is rather odd inasmuch as we have a fairly good understanding of the numbers that we need and the growth that we need. The problem is that this and previous governments have refused to finance the type of growth that we need. I think that any inquiry would better address its time to the availability of the resources from the Government either in this Budget or from future governments and, based on that make some determination. It is very easy. We know that we are, for example, short each year by between 13,000 to 20,000 places for young people who try to get into our tertiary institutions because we have failed to provide the money for them.

We find in this statement also that furphy that was run in the Budget, that somehow there are over 5,000 new places. But there are not; in fact only 3,000 new places are being funded and those additional 2,000 places will be taken at the expense of mature aged students. Let us get very clear what we are talking about-the money is not being provided. It is being provided only at a level of about $3,000 to $4,000 per student, yet overseas students are being charged upwards of $5,000 or $6,000. That is supposed to be full cost recovery and sometimes that is said to be 50 per cent of full cost recovery. The Government cannot have it both ways and say on the one hand `We are funding you to the tune of $3,500 to $4,000 and that is all you are getting for these new places' and on the other hand say to another group of individuals from overseas that the 50 per cent of full cost recovery is $5,500, which it is saying to some students in some courses.

The next item to be addressed is general productivity issues in higher education. We had the absurdity in the May mini-Budget when the Government said that cutting the amount of money available to the institutions would make them more efficient. The absurdity of that is exacerbated only by the previous item that I had referred to. The Government has said, `If you pick up more students, we will pay you less'.

The next paragraph in the Minister's speech refers to the scope for further improvement in efficiency from rationalisation of the operations of institutions. If $1m is cut, for example, from the budget of a major university, such as the University of Queensland in my State, presumably that is going to make it more efficient. By the same token, presumably cutting $2m off the Budget will make it twice as efficient, and cutting $3m off will make it three times more efficient. I think the Government has not come to grips with the operation of the various levels of the institutions in this country and what effort they are putting in. Whilst it is all very easy to knock academics and higher education institutions, I am sure that when everybody in this place and most people in the community need a good lawyer they make sure that they hire one who has been academically trained. Equally, when they want a doctor they want one who is properly trained, and when they want a dentist they also want one who is properly trained. Everybody wants the services of properly trained individuals, but they are quite happy to knock those institutions which produce that wide range of groups of people in our society, whether it be social workers, art historians or people interested in Aboriginal languages or whatever.

The point about Aboriginal languages is, I think, very interesting. If this Government and previous governments had funded the study of Aboriginal languages-which is one of the subjects mentioned by Mr Dawkins as being of any use-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) might not now be running around with the type of problems that he has, trying to fix up the Bicentennial. If that funding had been provided we might have known more about Aboriginal society and we might have understood it better and been willing to move to a proper accommodation of the just demands of the Aboriginal people of this country.

The next paragraph refers to the more effective use of limited resources by eliminating the `me too' approach to course developments in institutions. I am not against eliminating the unnecessary duplication of courses providing it is unnecessary duplication. Because a course happens to be taught in another institution does not necessarily mean that it is an unnecessary duplication, particularly if a student lives in Cairns and the course is being conducted in Hobart. This will apply until we are willing to put some money into student accommodation-which we have not been in the past-and until we are willing to fly students to, and accommodate them in different parts of this continent so that they can take part in the courses which are necessary for the fulfilment of their studies. About five years ago I advocated that rather than duplicating many of the things that have gone on in the previous five years we should spend some money on student accommodation, and since that time we have not done so.

The future of the present binary system will be looked into. During the last election campaign, on behalf of the Australian Democrats I said that we would be happy to look at a movement away from the binary system. There has been a development within colleges of advanced education that I think indicates that we in fact, if not in name, moved away from the binary system a fairly long time ago. However, I have the distinct feeling that the movement away from the binary system is not a way of seeking rationalisation and getting the proper names of proper institutions, but rather it is a means of saving money. I am quite sure that the piddling amount of money which is provided for research in our colleges of advanced education (CAEs) will be taken as a new benchmark for research in universities rather than the other way around. Not until we get a clear indication from the Government that it will raise the resource level of the CAEs to the level of universities in terms of research I think that we should stay precisely where we are, thank you very much. That also goes for the institutes of technology.

The statement goes on to mention that `without prejudice to academic freedom' the task force will look at a variety of issues, such as a reform of the tenure system, schemes for selective early retirement, staff management and appraisal systems and the provision of greater incentives for performance. However, the Minister fails to recognise that since a Senate report regarding tenure, there has in fact been a great movement in higher education institutions. Almost every institution in this country has schemes for selective early retirement. There are specific schemes for staff management and appraisal systems and there are incentives for performance and there has been a reform of the tenure system. In some cases this has been a poor move. I do not want to digress here by looking at the problems of tutors in our higher education institutions. Nevertheless, there have been movements but they have not been recognised in this statement. It seems as though the new Minister has decided that he will be the new broom and sweep this area clean, as the higher education institutions have been doing nothing since this matter was first raised in the Senate. As Senator Teague, who was Chairman of that Committee, said, the report was brought in on tenure. A lot has been done. I think it would only be fair that a major statement such as this, which is brought down in both chambers, should give some acknowledgment to the moves in the higher education institution area.

The statement mentions a range of measures to better distribute resources across the system. The points I made just now referred to that, but the Minister goes on, very oddly, to talk about two items. He mentions fees and reiterates the Australian Labor Party's view on fees. I must admit to being in a total quandary on what that means. I thought it referred to the imposition of fees, but presumably the statement says something about there not being an imposition of fees. Whilst we see new avenues for fees to be imposed in post-graduate studies and in technical and further education institutions, we see a whole new movement down the line to accommodate that particular item. I would imagine that the Liberal Party would have been happy with that-although Senator Teague did not suggest this-because it is only when full fees are applied that some movement of the private education institutions into the mainstream of higher education will take place.

As I have said in this place, the economics of private higher education institutions in Australia will not work unless they get subsidies from the Government. There is no such thing as a private education institution; let us get that clear. Some are subsidised more by the public purse, and some less.

The report mentions the reform of institutional management and decision-making processes, including changes to the operation of governing bodies and academic boards. A great deal has taken place in the past five years, but those changes yet again have not been acknowledged in the Minister's statement.

I think it is very important that we should look at the vital area of Commonwealth-State relations in higher education. We have had a jumble of operations in that regard. I think that this is a very important area that needs to be put under the microscope. However, I think it is rather odd that Commonwealth-State relations should be put under the microscope with a Commonwealth department looking at them. This is a very odd sort of situation. I cannot imagine that one would get very much co-operation from the State departments by going down that track.

I could not agree more about the balance of our approach to post-graduate education, particularly at the doctorate level. An absurd situation has developed in Australia where in percentage terms fewer people are undertaking higher education, particularly in terms of undertaking doctorates in this country, than has been the case for many years. This is an extraordinary situation that we are now confronting. In fact, we are actively turning away the very brightest people who have finished their undergraduate courses because we do not have the resources to develop their education. We spend $15,000 to $20,000 getting people through primary and secondary education and their first graduate degree and then we say that we cannot afford to go on. We spend that money but cannot afford to spend a few thousand dollars which we should be spending to capitalise on that work. This Government, as with the previous Fraser Government, has not been willing to put up that money for the development of our major resource, our citizens.

I welcome the comments that were made in regard to the requirements for teacher education. I hope that at long last we will get rid of the absurdity floating around this country that in fact we are oversupplied with teachers. Anybody who has actually visited schools will know that we have an acute shortage of computer teachers. We have an acute shortage of science teachers. In fact, in some of the high schools in Queensland, science-that is, physics and chemistry-is being taught by domestic science teachers because there is nobody else to teach this subject. In fact, English history teachers are teaching mathematics because we have no maths trained teachers. Those maths teachers have gone into computing education because we do not have any computer teachers.

At the moment this country is bereft of qualified teachers. I hope that members of this chamber and the other place will not spread the types of rumours that have turned young people off going into teaching. We are at a crisis point in terms of getting qualified teachers only because young people have been led to believe that there is no longer a teaching profession-a very hard profession but a profession nevertheless-and that there are not openings for them. There are openings and we need those people.

I would like to make many other points but about half of my time has been taken up by quorum calls. I hope that when the Government gets round to this inquiry, it does not have a departmental inquiry but will conduct a wider inquiry. The Government has identified major points of concern within the community. Let those points be of concern to the wider community and let that whole wider education community take part in such an inquiry. The inquiry should not be a little in-house job with the Government coming up with its own decisions which it has probably made already. The education community will not be convinced that those decisions have not been made already unless in fact that community is included in the wider study.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The results, as indicated in the 1987 annual report of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) which has just been tabled, are very significant for the year and reveal that the organisation had a very good year with a profit of about $68m. Of course, about $40m of that will be coming back to the Government by way of dividend in order to fund, no doubt, the reduced Budget deficit, which is a matter of some contention as a result of the Government's cooked figures in the Budget. Before going too far into this matter, I think it is interesting to note some of the real achievements of the OTC, which I am sure all honourable senators would agree has been a very successful and most worthwhile statutory body.

According to the information provided in the report, OTC has been a very profitable organisation when one compares its earnings with those of general media companies. Looking at the year ended 1986 we find that OTC made a profit on shareholders' funds of about 22.1 per cent compared with all media companies of 22.6 per cent-in other words, roughly the same. However, in the preceding year the comparison was some 22 per cent and 10.9 per cent. However, the profit of OTC as a percentage of shareholders' funds has now risen to 28 per cent. That is the kind of result we hope will continue as far as OTC is concerned.

Having noted that, it is important to note that in the report OTC's Managing Director, Mr George Maltby, draws attention to the challenges of the future for the OTC. In particular, he makes this comment:

Telecommunications services in Australia and around the world are undergoing major changes. Chief amongst the forces for change are the pressures from telecommunications users for a wider range of services at lower prices, and the emergence of technology which sweeps away past limitations.
It is that last comment to which I would like to draw attention because it is expanded on in an OTC Press statement which states:

Maltby said he believed government regulation should be reduced to the minimum necessary to guarantee the safety and integrity of the network. As far as possible, regulation should be a function of the interplay of market forces and competitive law.

This almost precisely sums up the position of the Liberal Party of Australia in relation to the OTC. Indeed, this is exactly what we have been advocating. Our policies reveal a stance in favour of the deregulation of bodies such as OTC. They need to be given maximum opportunities for developing all of their capacities in terms of providing Australians with an effective, sophisticated and up to date modern service, both within Australia and overseas.

I think that is the main message of the annual report. This is quite apart from the obvious incapacity of this Government to consider adequately the capital requirements of OTC. There has been some recent publicity within the Labor Party of an argument that has been going to and fro about whether it is necessary to fund more and more of the capital requirements of these companies from private sources. No doubt the Right, Left and Centre Left factions of the Australian Labor Party will have to work out whether the party will eventually support privatisation. However, the key point is that if one looks at a profit of about $70m and one requires about $40m of that to be paid back to the Government by way of dividend, and if one already has a massive investment of half a billion dollars or more, one is leaving very little in the kitty for the development of the new fibre optics technology, the new technologies that will be required for the future.

I believe that the time has come for the Government to face up to its responsibilities, to settle this very divisive argument that it is apparently having within its own organisation over the capital requirements of such bodies and to support the Opposition's position, which is the sale of 49 per cent of OTC to the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Academic Salaries Tribunal's annual report for 1986-87 is only a few pages and the first comment I wish to make is to commend Mr McKenzie, the member of the Tribunal, the person appointed for the one-year period from 24 July 1986. I note that he reported two days before the expiry of that year. His report is clear and concise. It also demonstrates that there is no continuing need for the Tribunal and that it should be dismantled. I note that there is nothing in the report that indicates that any substantial decision was taken during the past year. The cost of the Tribunal was a little over $6,000-$2,000 in salary to the member of the Tribunal for the few days of sitting that were required, some $2,000 in travel allowance and air fares and $2,000 in administrative costs.

There were only two activities of the Tribunal during the year. One was to note national wage decisions and the second was to receive two requests, both of which were quickly defused without there being any substantial decision. This demonstrates that given the present wage determination procedures in Australia and given the unionisation of academics and the initiative that can be taken by their employers in universities and colleges, there is no continuing need for the Academic Salaries Tribunal.

Finally, I refer to a matter which was touched on in responding to the statement by the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) less than an hour ago. The Liberal Party of Australia has called for a minimum of Commonwealth regulation. In `The Growth Plan for Higher Education', the policy put forward by the coalition before the last election, we had a reference under the heading `A Minimum of Commonwealth Regulation'. It says:

The restoration of academic and administrative autonomy to higher education institutions is central to our policy plans. We believe that the higher education system will more effectively satisfy the diverse demands placed upon it if control resides with each institution, rather than the Commonwealth Government.
We look forward to higher education institutions:
determining their own admission policies;
deciding their own staff policies;
choosing their own special emphases and interests;
interacting with the community as they see fit; and
planning their own futures.

Consistent with these expectations, the next Liberal/National Party Government will dismantle the Academic Salaries Tribunal so that institutions and their employees are again free directly to establish mutually satisfactory arrangements for salaries and conditions of employment. As a consequence of the changed nature of the funding of higher education, we will also allow . . .
