Before I speak to this motion and the motion to follow I suggest that when it comes to debates and amendments we deal with them item by item, with the concurrence of the chamber, for the convenience of honourable senators. At the moment we have before us a committee system designed by a committee. Following the last election there was some desire evinced by back- bench members of the Australian Labor Party to look again at the committee system, not just in this chamber but also in the other place. Accordingly, a committee was elected by Caucus-a committee of seven-to look at the committee system. This committee has come up with a variety of suggestions, which survived the Ministry with a few minuscule changes, survived the Caucus with a couple more adjustments, and now appear before us today having been further amended to try to anticipate some of the views of the Opposition and minority groups in this chamber.

We will try as much as possible to co-operate in order to get a general consensus approach, if you like, to the committee system. Like all compromises it probably has some irrationalities still within it. Of course, the major committee reform does not occur in this chamber. It occurs in the House of Representatives, which in the next two or three days will have a fairly full and comprehensive committee system for the first time. There has been an attempt as much as possible to have a mirror image set of committees in the Senate for the convenience of the parties and for people's understanding of each committee's work. There is a desire on all sides to make sure that the Senate and House of Representatives committees are not considering exactly the same reference, which I think we would all agree is a waste of resources. As it currently appears, the committee structure will again enhance the activities of this chamber, based on its previous work. The way in which these committees are set up means that again we should have some fairly comprehensive reports come into this chamber-reports written and arrived at in a slightly different atmosphere from that of debates in this chamber. Quite often governments are quite willing to accept the views of committees once they have looked at some of these items where previously they would never have given countenance to such suggestions. I commend the various suggestions to the Senate for its consideration and look forward to Opposition and other comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in Senator Robert Ray's description of this committee system having been designed by a committee. Of course, the old saying is `A camel is a horse designed by a committee' but I prefer the definition of a committee as being like `a baby with a loud voice at one end and no sense of responsibility at the other'. I will not say that this committee had no sense of responsibility. In fact it has drawn the attention of the Senate to a large number of matters which we must consider. Our committee system has been one of the great achievements of this Senate. For more than 50 years we have had a Senate Committee on Regulations and Ordinances which is by far the most effective method of control over delegated legislation in any Westminster-style parliament. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills is in my opinion a model for all parliaments. The eight legislative and general purpose standing committees, set up in the early 1970s with all party support, played an important part in the Senate performing its role of critically examining the actions and proposed legislation of successive governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Now the House of Representatives proposes to set up its own committee structure loosely modelled on ours. I have severe doubts whether the committee structure in the House of Representatives will function effectively because, under responsible government, committees in the popular House will always be controlled by the government of the day. There is no way in which a competent Minister, party discipline being what it is, would permit committees to delve into areas the Minister does not want delved into. These are the very areas-whether they be actions or proposed Bills-which should be delved into by an effective committee system to find out why the government does not want them looked at. Nevertheless, we wish the House of Representatives well in its intentions and hope that its committees will be more effective than I think they will be.

We must ensure at all costs that the setting up of these committees in the House of Representatives does not damage the effectiveness of our committee system here in the Senate. For the great quality of the committee system in the Senate is that it has not been controlled by the Government. Even during the six years from 1975 to 1981 when the Senate was controlled by the then Government there was sufficient feeling among Government senators of the importance of the committee system so that it continued to function free of government shackles, or excessive government controls. For instance, the Freedom of Information Bill was referred to a Senate standing committee during that period, because sufficient Government senators thought that the proposed Bill needed substantial public examination. One consequence-perhaps the only beneficial consequence-of the 1984 increase in the size of the Senate is to make it unlikely, at any rate for the foreseeable future, that any government will control the Senate.

I am not saying that our system of legislative and general purpose committees is perfect. It is not. We have referred far too few Bills to these committees for public examination. Although almost everyone agrees that Bills that have been referred to standing committees for public examination have been substantially improved as a result, or at the very least that the subsequent debate in the Senate has been more informed, despite these advantages, governments of whatever persuasion will always be very reluctant to see their Bills subjected to such a process. I would like to see an improved mechanism for referring Bills to committee, and a greatly increased flow of such Bills to committees, and I shall be moving an amendment to that end in this debate.

I repeat that the key reason for the effectiveness of the Senate committee system is that the structure is set up by agreement of all parties in the Senate, and the activities of the committees are not dominated by the Government. In the Opposition's view, the original motion to amend Standing Orders proposed by Senator Gareth Evans was defective in a number of ways. I should like to pay tribute to Senator Robert Ray for the reasonableness and open-mindedness with which he handled our criticisms of the original motion. I shall not go any further in praising him, Mr President, for fear that I might damage his reputation among his colleagues for ruthlessness.

The agreements that were reached to meet the Opposition's concerns were these: first, we were concerned that foreign affairs, trade and defence would not be covered by a Senate committee, the surveillance being left to a joint committee, over which the Senate would have no control. We believe that it is fundamental that the Senate committee system should cover all areas of government activity. The Government has agreed to reinstate the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and this is reflected in the motion that is before us. Our second concern was over the question of separate Estimates committees. The arguments for and against separate Estimates committees-that is, whether they should be covered by the legislative and general purpose committees-are narrowly balanced, but the Opposition felt that the balance of argument was in favour of the continuation of separate Estimates committees. The Government agreed to this, and elimination of the Estimates committees is not in the motion before us.

Thirdly, although the Opposition strongly supported the re-establishment of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare because of the important work it is doing, we were concerned that it would have four members only. As two of the places would go to the Government and one to the Australian Democrats, this left only one place for the Opposition. Although the Liberal and National parties in opposition are working very closely together, we are in fact two separate parties and we want to have a position available for both a Liberal senator and a National Party senator. The Government has agreed to an increase in the committee size to six which permits that.

The Opposition was also mildly concerned about the handling of public works. In the past public works of over $6m have been considered by a joint committee of the House of Representatives and the Senate. Under the Government's proposals this activity would be handled solely by a House of Representatives committee. Although it would obviously be absurd to have two separate committees, one in the Senate and one in the House of Representatives, looking at public works proposals, the Opposition was concerned at the non-involvement of senators in this important function, and the Government has agreed to re-examine the problem.

Fifthly, the Opposition was concerned about its representation on the standing committees. By the Standing Orders, the committee size, unless otherwise ordered, is six-three government and three non-government. This meant that if an Independent or Australian Democrat senator joined the committee-and we would welcome that senator's involvement-the Opposition numbers would fall to two, unless the committee size were increased. The Government has agreed to do this, to ensure that Opposition representation on these committees is three in every case. We are very grateful for that concession, which we recognise imposes difficulty on the Government which has only 23 senators available for all the Senate committee positions. This means that a number of Government senators have to serve on more than one committee. We understand the Government's problem and are grateful to it for meeting our difficulties.

Finally, there is the question of co-ordination of the activities of the standing committees. During the time of the coalition Government there was an informal grouping of the chairmen of the legislative and general purpose standing committees. The Opposition feels that this organisation should be formalised and that the group should meet under the chairmanship of the Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. This is a bit awkward for me, Mr President, but in the House of Representatives the proposal was that this function should be carried out by the Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees. There seems no reason why the function of that position in the Senate should be different in this area from that in the House of Representatives. The fact that there will be members of different parties involved in such a committee serves to emphasise the non-party nature of the Senate committee system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go on; you can handle eight Labor chairmen with no difficulty.

—I think that I could handle them, but perhaps I would be outvoted on occasion. The Government has undertaken to consider this matter, and I therefore put to it the following suggestions of what the functions of such a committee should be. First, it should review periodically the work load of the various legislative and general purpose standing committees and, if necessary, make recommendations as to changes in responsibility for government departments to even out the work load; and in the event of a reorganisation of the government, propose to the Senate any necessary changes in committee responsibilities for the various government departments. Secondly, it should make any necessary representations to the Standing Committee on Staffing and Appropriations. Thirdly, it should make regular reports to the Senate on the activities of the standing committees.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, the Opposition is grateful to the Government, and to Senator Robert Ray in particular, for the way in which they have handled our concerns in these areas. Nevertheless, some difficulties remain. I should like to enumerate them for the benefit of the Senate. I will go briefly through the proposed amendments to Standing Orders as moved by the Government and I will point out the attitudes of the Opposition and the amendments I intend to move on its behalf.

I deal first with standing order 33. It is proposed to change the name of the Standing Orders Committee to the Procedure Committee. The Opposition has no objection to this. The proposed name seems to describe more accurately the real functions of this Committee. Standing order 36a is being amended to reduce the membership of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances from 7 to 6, and to make provision for non-Government and non-Opposition senators to be members. The Opposition has no objection to this or to the consequential amendments.

The amendment to standing order 36aa deals with the new standing committees. Here we have a number of criticisms which I shall deal with in turn. First of all, for reasons that have not been explained, the description of the committees as legislative and general purpose committees has been dropped. These eight committees are a generic group-they are not the only standing committees; there is quite a number of other standing committees-and it is convenient to distinguish them from other standing committees such as domestic committees like the Library and House committees. I have heard no reason why this description was suddenly removed, but I fear it might be because the Government does not like the suggestion that these committees might actually look at legislation. It is worth noting that the House of Representatives committee would have no power to look at legislation. To make quite clear the very important role of these committees, I shall be moving an amendment to reinsert the words `Legislative and General Purpose Committees' to describe these eight committees.

Our second problem is that we do not think the names of these eight committees are very happily chosen. The Clerk of the House of Representatives wrote a paper on a committee structure for the House of Representatives in which he proposed a structure loosely based on the Senate's structure, but deliberately chose different names for the proposed House of Representatives committees to avoid confusion with the corresponding Senate committees. When the Australian Labor Party Caucus committee considered this matter it adopted, with some modifications, the deliberately different names chosen by the Clerk of the House of Representatives, and then decided that the Senate committee names should be changed to bring them into line with the names for the House of Representatives committees-the very thing the Clerk of the House was trying to avoid.

Incidentally, in the United States Congress, where the two Houses have parallel committees, in nearly every case the two committees have different names. There is a clear necessity to avoid irritating confusion and, although there are strong arguments in favour of parallel functions, there are equally strong arguments in favour of different names. This is a complex issue, and one on which I believe the members of the Senate committees concerned should be consulted. So I will be moving an amendment which would provide that the names listed in the Government's motion would be provisional only, allowing the Senate committees, if they choose, to propose to the Senate an alteration to their titles. For instance, we had a well-known committee called the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, colloquially known as the `F and GO Committee'. For no apparent reason this motion proposes that that committee be known as the Finance and Public Administration Committee. I think its members would rather it be known as the F and GO Committee. Anyway, I think this is a matter which should be further considered in the calmer atmosphere of committees, and any changes the members want should come back to this chamber for decision.

The Opposition also strongly supported the concept behind the Government's proposals that every government department should be clearly covered by one or other of the eight legislative and general purpose standing committees. This responsibility was made clear when these committees were also to deal with Estimates. But when the decision to retain separate Estimates committees was made this clear linking was lost. I shall therefore be moving an amendment, based on the Government's original motion, to assign primary responsibility for each government department to one or other of the Senate legislative and general purpose standing committees.

Perhaps the area of greatest concern is the amendment to paragraph 1 of standing order 36aa which gives each of the standing committees the power to confer or sit as a joint committee with a similar committee of the House of Representatives. The provenance of this provision is curious. It was not proposed in the report of the Clerk of the House of Representatives, nor in the Labor Party committee report to Caucus. It seems to have been inserted, as far as I can gather, by the Executive for what I think are very ominous reasons. The great strength of the Senate committee system has been its independence from the Executive and the power of the Senate-and the Senate alone-to give tasks to these committees. This innocent looking provision would mean that power being taken away from the Senate.

Let us look at the options open to a Minister who was concerned that a Senate committee was probing into areas that he did not want to probe into. Under the arrangements to be introduced in the House of Representatives, the Minister would be able to task the House of Representatives committees directly. If he wanted he could give them all sorts of interesting studies and investigations in areas he did not mind being investigated. Then, without consulting the Senate-remembering that the Senate committees are controlled by the Government, with which we do not disagree-a Senate committee could link up with a House of Representatives committee and effectively we would have our Senate committees being tasked by Ministers. This linking, by the way, could be done without the Senate even being informed. We could well find that when we wished to give one of our committees a task-to work at a particular problem or perhaps to examine legislation-we would be told that it was fully occupied in investigations ordered by the Minister. I believe that this proposal must be rejected if the Senate committee system is to survive as a proper inquisitorial system free of government control.

The Opposition, the Minister will be delighted to hear, has no objection to the deletion of standing order 38 and consequential amendments. The Committee of Disputed Returns and Qualifications has not met for nearly 80 years. On the subject of the sitting of Senate and joint committees during Senate sessions, the Opposition is not prepared to accept the revised provision that these committees may sit in private, but not public, session during Senate sittings. We should prefer that they did not sit at all during Senate sittings, but if the Senate decides they should sit, we think the provision should make it clear that committee votes may not be taken while the Senate is in session. I think the reason for that is fairly obvious. We might well find that, if a committee were sitting, senators might be called for proper duties in the Senate, and it would be outrageous if a committee could then take a vote in their absence.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they played that trick we would just call quorums.

—I think we will leave the question of quorums out of this debate. We want to get on with it without digressions. I shall be moving an amendment also on the question of the organised referral of Bills to committees. Although these committees are described as legislative and general purpose committees-and, despite the Government's wishes, I think they will continue as such-the amount of legislative work they have done is very small, perhaps two or three Bills a year out of the 200 or so passed by the Senate. One of the problems is that whenever proposals are made to refer Bills to committees, the committee chairmen-always Government senators, of course-have said that their committee is too busy on other work to undertake such a task. I think we have to have a more orderly consideration of which Bills would benefit from public examination by a Senate committee and I will be moving an amendment-the one of which Senator Chaney gave notice in the last Senate-to give effect to this.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise one final matter. This motion is a proposed amendment to Standing Orders. It is very substantial and, as I believe this debate will show, it has some proposals which are controversial. In particular, the distribution of activities to the various legislative and general purpose standing committees has been criticised as unequal and not representing a reasonable span of interests of likely committee members. Whether these objections have substance only time will tell, but I think it would be appropriate for the restructuring of the committee system to be enacted as a sessional order rather than as an amendment to Standing Orders. I shall be moving an amendment to that effect. The advantage of having it as a sessional order is that it will force the Government of the day to bring these matters back to the Senate in the next session when senators can make their views felt as to whether this substantial modification of the existing system is working satisfactorily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to go into all the details of this matter and certainly do not wish to give the sort of run-down that Senator Hamer has given. I just indicate on behalf of the Australian Democrats that we will be proposing only one amendment to the Government's proposed amendments to Standing Orders, which will deal with standing order 36aa. I want to make it clear, however, that we do not see as arising out of the exercise the vaguely conspiratorial problems that Senator Hamer sees. We see something quite different. To us the difficulties do not relate to the non-government majority in this chamber being able to stop any rampaging government from filling up Senate committee times. If we are so asleep in this chamber we deserve to have the committee times filled up.

SPEECH.PARA: But there is a procedural problem that has concerned us. I refer to the Government's proposed amendments to standing order 36aa, particularly the part which confers on standing committees the ability to sit jointly. To give an example, let us say that a Senate committee decides to sit with a House of Representatives committee with a similar name which is conducting a hearing into an item referred to it by the House of Representatives, not the Senate, that witnesses are present and that there is not a quorum of House of Representatives members. If for some reason or other-I am sure this would not apply to any of the honourable senators in the chamber-those present get rather contentious and wander into making defamatory remarks, or lead a witness into making defamatory statements, and the witness concerned decides to go to court, what will be the standing of the senators with regard to privilege? It is not at all clear what their standing will be.

That is a difficulty and I do not believe that we should expose honourable senators to possible problems down the line in that regard. The courts have made some fairly erratic decisions in the past with regard to parliamentary privilege and I do not want to dangle out to them an opportunity to do so again in the future by our passing a motion which is in a sense defective. There is no problem, however, with the ability to confer. I think it is perfectly reasonable that a Senate committee ought to be able to nip down to a House of Representatives committee and say, `We want to look at some of the material you have on such and such a reference. It might be useful for us', or, `We would like to sit in on the questioning of a particular witness'. I think that is perfectly reasonable, but I think the joint sitting of committees would raise problems of privilege.

I can see times when the joint sitting of committees might be useful. For example, the Government has now accepted an Opposition proposal to have both a joint committee and a Senate committee on foreign affairs, defence and trade. If a particular witness, such as an overseas witness, is being questioned by the joint committee-that occurs fairly regularly-it would be useful for the two committees to be able to sit together, at least to give the Senate committee the opportunity of questioning the witness.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no problem at the moment.

—There is not really any problem but I am saying that we could allow that to occur in a formal sense. I think it might be useful on such an occasion and on others. But in that event there would be no problem in seeking from the Senate approval for two committees to sit as one. I am quite sure that the Senate would give such approval, after being given the reasons in the short space of time that would take-it would be only one or two minutes-because members of the Opposition, the Democrats and the Government who sit on those committees have already determined that it is a reasonable prospect. Hence the thing will be coughed through anyhow. I do not see any major problems in seeking such a reference from the Houses on occasions, and I hope there will be a number of occasions when committees wish to sit jointly. I think it is a useful development.

SPEECH.PARA: We were willing to accept the standing committees operating as Estimates committees. We saw advantages in this. We are particularly interested in developing standing committees as high-powered committees. We hoped not only that such committees would undertake references, thereby getting a detailed understanding of the policy side and, through that, being better able to engage in an Estimates inquiry, but also that further down the line those committees would undertake specific audits to replace the rather odd operations that often take place in the Estimates committees when we drag in every bod from around Australia and keep witnesses waiting in the corridors for ages, some of whom, when they come in here, are not asked any questions at all. There are costs involved.

I would hope that down the line standing committees may pick a particular part of a department that they have investigated or touched on in undertaking a policy reference and really go through their operations doing a good audit as only this chamber can do. I refer not to the type of departmental audit conducted by internal and external auditors but one which would be done by this chamber. I believe that it was partly the intention of a government committee to look into that type of activity. As I said, I do not lean much towards the conspiracy theories and I think it can be shown that the Government was genuine in the developments it was proposing by its ready acceptance of a whole range of items put up by the Opposition. Senator Hamer has graciously accepted that the Government did display good will in this regard. I hope that what the Government was seeking to achieve in that development will not be put aside and that we may see further intrusive inquiries by the standing committees into the operations of departments.

Most of the other points that Senator Hamer raised he has raised with me. I accepted those points. However, we will not be supporting them. I think arguments can be put for each one and, if required, I will be quite happy to put the arguments of my Party as to why we were happy to give the operation proposed by the Government a trial. We were inclined initially to accept that the amendments proposed to the standing orders should take the form of sessional orders. However, the Government has accepted the major problems, apart from names, that the Opposition has raised. Therefore, we feel that there is not a great deal of substance left in these changes. We are happy enough to accept them as standing orders. I say to the Opposition that if the operation goes disastrously wrong at some stage we will be quite happy to look at it. After all, given the overwhelming predominance of non-government senators in this place, it will be quite easy to bring on a debate on this matter if we want to do so. It is as easy, under those circumstances, to change standing orders as it is to change sessional orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some things need to be said about the proposal to change dramatically the committee structure of the Senate. I can understand, perhaps, that the Government wants to establish a committee structure in the House of Representatives. One might be cynical in thinking that it is to keep those on the back benches out of mischief by giving them something to do. But even that is not particularly convincing when we see the way the House of Representatives forces Bills through with scarcely any significant or relevant debate. If it took its Bills more seriously and looked at legislation in more depth we might think that something would flow from that and that it would want to look at the other matters and have a committee structure. But when we observe from Hansard the way it deals with legislation I do not see that there is very much to be said in favour of its having a committee structure, particularly in light of the way it is proposed to be put together and the control that Ministers will have over it.

SPEECH.PARA: The extent to which the Government wishes to link the Senate with a House of Representatives committee structure leads me to conclude that the whole exercise is designed to erode the status of the Senate, status it has acquired because of the good inquiries that it has undertaken over the years. I commend Senator Robert Ray on the modifications to the original scheme, which are now before the Senate, but I still feel that my comments in relation to its background are relevant.

I applaud the fact that the Estimates committees are to be preserved. I disagree with Senator Hamer only on his point that the arguments are narrowly balanced. The reasons why the Estimates committees should be retained were convincing. The people on the committees which investigate and report probably differ from those who look into the financial structure of departments, and it would be a pity if that system were broken. Caucus decided to explore the idea of a committee system in the House of Representatives. Suddenly, the Senate was swept up in the move and our system dramatically changed. We could have been left with a good committee system, such as the one we had, perhaps one involving more co-operation with joint committees, if that were desirable. The decision has been made with little explanation to the Senate as to why our system needed to be changed. There is little benefit in the proposal.

We have heard about the names and groupings. There seems to be no logic in the proposal, other than to meet the present administrative arrangements. I should have thought that the aim of a Senate committee system would be committees with names similar to those we have had for years and with the opportunity to look into the full range of government activities. To link them to the administrative arrangements which are made from time to time is a retrograde step. It shows a desire to undermine the purpose of Senate committees. I hope that that is not true, but the way in which the system is put together leads me to conclude that it is. Undoubtedly, there will be confusion for the media, witnesses and departments and, from what we have seen this week, probably even confusion between Ministers.

The same argument applies to the change of names. Senator Hamer has spelt out the reasons why the Senate should retain its original names, and I support his amendment. The committee should be allowed to consider the names and report to the Senate before these ridiculous changes are made. I suppose that it is of no consequence that a financial burden will be involved in changing the names. Even the stationery for the old committees will have to be thrown out and new stationery printed. There is no reason to do that and, undoubtedly, there will be confusion and a cost burden.

I shall not go through all the canvassed arguments-they were well put by Senator Hamer-but I could not speak without commenting on the balance of the matters which each committee will investigate. Some committees will be extremely busy if they cover all aspects properly, or some aspects will not be pursued in depth. Industry, technology, commerce, industrial relations, primary industries and energy are in one grouping and the Attorney-General's Department is in another. Either the system is designed to ensure that some matters will not be given any attention or the Government does not understand what the committees should contribute to Parliament's work. The load is very uneven.

The Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory is quietly to be abolished. The paper which went to Caucus referred under the heading `Public Works and Infrastructure' to the functions of what would be only a House of Representatives committee. The paper stated:
Functions would include those of the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works and Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory.
I shall list the other functions to show what is happening to the Territory in this little manoeuvre. The paper stated:
functions to be expanded to include ability to conduct other enquiries
Transport and Communications-
a big matter-
Administrative Services (excluding Electoral Reform)-
that was lucky-
takes over role of the Transport Safety Committee
the Public Works Committee Act would need to be amended to change the committee from a joint committee to a House of Representatives committee
the committee would not have statutory rights in enquiries not referred to it under the Public Works Committee Act

Where would the Australian Capital Territory finish in such a committee? I am sure that the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) will tell us that these matters will be considered by a self-governing body in the Australian Capital Territory `in time'. But in what time? Why should not the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory be preserved until that time so that the people of the Australian Capital Territory retain the same access to Parliament that they have had since the Joint Committee was set up in 1957?

I remind the Senate of some of the Joint Committee's more recent inquiries. In 1981 the Committee reported on `Energy Use, Distribution and Conservation in the Australian Capital Territory'. Later it reported on `Retail Trading Hours in the ACT', `Parliamentary Zone Draft Development Plan', `Murrumbidgee River in the ACT Region', `Hospitality in the ACT' and the metropolitan plan of Canberra-all large inquiries. In addition, since 1981 the Committee has dealt with a series of variations to the city plan of Canberra, from the seventy-fifth to the last, the ninetieth.

Lest honourable senators should think that variations to the city plan of Canberra are of no consequence, I remind them of a recent variation-the minor road variation in the city to enable section 78 of the city plan to be developed as proposed, thus closing a small portion of Ainslie Avenue. That detailed inquiry brought forward all the arguments on parking problems in Civic. It brought before the Committee the Burley Griffin plan and his proposal for access from City Hill to Mount Ainslie. The committee considered the impact of parking on the suburb of Reid. I could take a great deal of time giving more information. These issues, with the changes to the plan of Canberra, have been brought before the Joint Committee and enabled the Territory's citizens to express their views on matters of great concern to them. Without self-government there has been no other forum. Once the Australian Capital Territory has its assembly, that will be taken care of. In the absence of such a local assembly, the Joint Committee has filled an important role.

I could consider a number of issues in recent years showing how what might seem to be a minor variation to the city plan of Canberra has enabled a full and in-depth inquiry to be made. The Joint Committee is not a planning committee, but some of the matters which it has had to consider recently have almost made it appear as though the Committee were a part of the planning function. To bury this Committee in a public works and infrastructure committee, where little attention can be paid to changes in the city plan, is not looking after the national capital in the way the Government should. The new committee's work will mean that there will be no time for in-depth inquiries such as those of the past which included a review of the metropolitan plan and an inquiry into the hospitality industry, from which significant conclusions have come.

Only last week in the Budget, I am pleased to say, the Government responded to the hospitality industry inquiry report, which made the same recommendation as the Joint Committee had made previously-that the Food School at the Reid College of Technical and Further Education should be expanded to give young people training in skills where there are available jobs. Those who inquire of some of the Canberra people who, since the Joint Committee was established in 1957, have had the opportunity to make submissions and be heard will find that those people are disappointed, to put it in its politest terms, that this last vestige of communication with government is to be withdrawn. In the Budget last week most statutory authorities and advisory committees in the Territory were abolished.

That was done in the name of savings. It is funny, really, how the Government can abolish all these authorities to save a few shillings or dollars but it can change all the names of the Senate committees and say, `To heck with the cost of doing that'.

TALK.START.PARA: —And have three new Ministers.

—Yes, there are three new Ministers as well. Marvellous, is it not? But, when it comes to a bit of representation for the Australian Capital Territory, the Government is not prepared to put up an electoral system that is fair or to put a proposal to enable self-government to come into effect. It is certainly quick at abolishing any means that the community has of communicating with government and having a say in things. Let us not forget that, even when self-government does come into effect and there is a community government in Canberra, there will still be areas where there will need to be a partnership between an Australian Capital Territory government and the national government. There are areas where that relationship will need to continue. I would have thought that, even after self-government in the Australian Capital Territory, there would be functions that ought to be performed by a joint parliamentary committee on the Australian Capital Territory. Members of the Senate and of this Parliament ought to want to preserve for themselves the right and the place to have such an input. For the Senate to let these functions be buried away in the new Public Works and Infrastructure Committee-which is still just to be a House of Representatives committee; I hope that will be changed-is really to renege on some of its responsibilities to the national capital.

SPEECH.PARA: Without going into great detail on these matters and to sum up, I think the whole proposal with relation to the Australian Capital Territory is unfair and unreasonable. As far as the Senate committees are concerned, I regard the proposal as downgrading them. I conclude by saying that I am pleased with the changes that have been made to the original proposals; this is not quite as bad as the original proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak against the cut in resources to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. It is unfortunate that the number of expert staff that the Committee has available to help to maintain its significant work on behalf of the Parliament is to be severely cut. Unfortunately, this cut will not only hamstring and curtail the activities of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts but also reduce the number of inquiries that it can undertake. On the one hand, while it will make life very much more comfortable for government, on the other hand governments will miss out on much of the expertise because the reports of the Committee were essentially constructed as an aid in the stewardship function of a responsible parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: After all the horse-trading that has gone on, I suppose we should be grateful that we do at least have a Public Accounts Committee, although a shackled one, in existence. Over time, with the setting up of these new committees in the House of Representatives, the Government will find that it will be fairly difficult for the Opposition to man a number of these committees as effectively as the Government expects. That is a fact of life. The fact that the secretarial staff assisting the committees will not be increased will mean that the joint committees must be reduced in effectiveness, and so must the Senate committees. I am surprised that the Senate has taken so lightly the reduction in resources to be made available not only to joint committees but also to the Senate committees.

The concept of a Public Accounts Committee is one of the features of the British Parliament that the Australian Parliament and all the State parliaments, with the exception of Queensland, have adopted. The history of the Public Accounts Committee shows that not only has the Committee earned a significant role in the Parliament in the 1980s and beyond but also that it has been consistently maintained by all governments of all political colours. The Committee's role was even expanded during the last Parliament to meet the need for increased scrutiny. But the Government wants to reduce the expert and overworked Public Accounts Committee Secretariat to only five-to one-third of its current complement. There has been some suggestion that that figure may be increased. In addition, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, still wants the Committee to examine major computer acquisitions, including the important $700m purchase by the Australian Taxation Office. I submit that there has not been enough liaison between the Minister co-ordinating the setting up of these committees and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Finance Minister.

The Public Accounts Committee is still expected to approve the appointment of independent auditors and has always been consulted and expected to comment upon all changes to the Audit Act. In fact no changes have been made to the Committee's duties as outlined in section 8 of the Public Accounts Committee Act, yet this Committee is expected to continue with those responsibilities but with only one-third of its current staff. At the very least the secretariat, which as Deputy Chairman of that Committee I am proud to say has so expertly and loyally served the Committee, must be maintained at its present numbers if the Parliament is to keep a demonstrated, efficient and worthwhile scrutiny of the public sector. This is what is at risk under this Government's proposals.

I submit that the Public Accounts Committee has undertaken many significant inquiries and subsequently reports. I will mention just a few of them. In October 1982, the Committee produced a report entitled The Selection and Development of Senior Managers in the Commonwealth Public Service. This subsequently led to the establishment of the Senior Executive Service. More recently, many of the ideas were endorsed by the Block report, the report by the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit of Proposed Successor Arrangements of the Public Service Board. These reports have been constructive and ongoing and have been picked up by this Government. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) embraced these reorganisations and yet his Government now seeks to stunt this Committee that played such a large part in their fruition.

I remind the Senate that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was established under the Public Accounts Committee Act of 1951. It was one of five committees established by statute. It is composed of government and opposition members of both Houses of the Parliament. It operates under its Act with complete independence; perhaps that is the concern of the Government. It determines its own program of work and the inquiries that it should undertake and has consultation with Ministers and with the Auditor-General. Unlike some of the House of Representatives committees, it does not accept directions from Ministers per se. Each House of the Parliament may refer any question relating to public accounts for inquiry and report. The Joint Standing Orders may assign other duties to the Committee.

I remind the Senate that in the last Parliament the Public Accounts Committee produced 55 reports-significantly more than any other committee of the Parliament. However, if its resources are to be depleted, we can look forward to only between 19 and 22 reports. It will cut the reporting ability to the Parliament, and it will affect the scrutiny of public accounts and so on.

In November 1981 the Public Accounts Committee produced a comprehensive handbook entitled Commonwealth Government Financial Administration- A Handbook, which is used by people from high school to government level in order to understand the financial infrastructure and institutions of the Australian Federal Government. The Public Accounts Committee also produced a very valuable report on standards of financial reporting for Commonwealth undertakings, as well as reviewing the guidelines for departmental annual reports to ensure a high standard of disclosure. These sorts of things will certainly be at risk as a result of the depletion in resources. I appeal to the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray)-he is not even in the chamber at the moment-to listen to these arguments and to improve these resources.

It seems that things are all cut and dried. It seems that the Government is no longer interested in scrutiny. It wants to go on its own merry way, to determine its own agenda and reduce the chance of the legislative branch being able to carry out its proper role. We have all too often heard that the power of the Executive is increasing. This matter before the Senate today will only increase the power of the Executive over the legislative branch and as such is to be deplored.

I have mentioned only three reports of the Public Accounts Committee. Other significant reports recently have included those relating to medifraud, defence project management, the Department of Social Security Stratplan project and a review of the Australian Capital Territory and repatriation hospitals. As I mentioned, in the last Parliament the Committee presented 55 reports of varying complexity. Every year exhaustive examinations of different departments and authorities and their programs were carried out. A forthcoming reference is a review, on behalf of the whole Parliament, of an audit of the Parliament House Construction Authority on the arrangements surrounding our new home. The Public Accounts Committee, to maintain its current level of efficiency and respect, must not have its secretariat reduced. I hope that the Minister for Home Affairs, who has just come into the chamber, will reconsider his plan to reduce the resources available to the Public Accounts Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is some arrangement between the Government and the Opposition that will enable us to deal with this matter reasonably expeditiously, so I will be brief. However, let me say from the outset that I am not yet able to understand why it is the Government's wish to amend Standing Orders and not sessional orders.
—We will give in on that; we don't care.
—The Government will give in on that? Okay.
—Sit down.

—Hang on! If it is that easy I will go on. Let us get on to something else that I can seduce Senator Ray into agreeing to. While Senator Ray is in such a generous mood let us consider the amendment to standing order 300, the addition of proposed standing order 300a, which provides for committees to meet in private for deliberations-I see Senator Ray shaking his head but he has not heard me out yet; he is about to be convinced-during the time the Senate is in session. It seems to me that it is not wise to require senators to attend Senate committee meetings and attend to their duties in the Senate at the same time. Perhaps I have a rather old fashioned and, as I said earlier, quaint view about the role and the function of the Senate chamber, but in my view the real risk is that the functioning and operation of the Senate chamber will be diluted and downgraded in favour of the committee system. The balance between the two is already very fragile.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my view that if the Senate chamber is to be a proper continuing debating forum, if we are to have intelligent, robust and informed debate and if the Senate chamber is to discover and debate the whole range of issues which senators are required to address, there ought not to be compulsory distractions of senators by Senate committees. As I said earlier, the real risk is that the functions of the Senate chamber will be usurped by the functions of the committee system. The problem can be simply overcome by continuing the present system of having Senate committees meet outside the hours of the Senate. I already spend between 12 and 13 hours a week travelling backwards and forwards between my electorate and Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —But under my other hat I have to pay for it.

—If Senator Ray is paying for it, it is the best investment he has made since he has been a Minister-after his salary, no doubt. It is an integral responsibility of all senators to fulfil their obligations to the committee system. If the committee system is to function properly it requires full and proper deliberation and attention which can be achieved only by having the meetings outside the times when the Senate is meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be interested to hear from Senator Ray how he allocated the various departments under each committee. The Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology covers references concerning the departments of Industry, Technology and Commerce, Industrial Relations and Primary Industries and Energy. So references concerning our export departments, all our export earning industries and all our wealth generating industries are under the one committee. Primary industry, non-farm industry, manufacturing industry, industrial relations, technology and commerce are all under the one committee. I put it to Senator Ray, with respect, that very few senators have either an interest or expertise in that whole gambit, that whole range, of departments. Many senators will have an interest in rural matters-the farming industry, the pastoral industry. Some honourable senators will have an interest in the mining sector. Some senators will have an exclusive interest in the manufacturing sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not many, unfortunately.

—Perhaps Senator Watson is right. Some honourable senators will have an interest in industrial relations but not in manufacturing, farming or mining. So we are reducing the potential resources available to these committees by having senators on the Industry, Science and Technology Committee who have only limited interest in some aspects of it. If we divided that committee into a more sensible committee it would have the full benefit of all its members.

SPEECH.PARA: I compare that Committee with the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. They are compelling topics, no doubt-likely to change the course of history. But the Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee, which covers references concerning the Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, is hardly a committee whose work load will cause its members to have a nervous breakdown. Yet it sits there, in splendid isolation, alongside the mammoth Industry, Science and Technology Committee.

The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration covers references concerning the departments of Parliament, Finance, Prime Minister and Cabinet and Treasury. Will Senator Ray tell me about Prime Minister and Cabinet? Then there is Treasury. The bottom line is that the Finance and Public Administration Committee is Treasury, and nothing else. The Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training is again a very light committee. References concerning the Department of Industrial Relations could very easily have come under that Committee. The Senate Standing Committee on Infrastructure covers references concerning the departments of Transport and Communications and Administrative Services-again a very light committee. It could have been attached to one of the other committees.

Finally, there is the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I remind honourable senators that in the terms of reference undertaken in the last several years by both the Senate and joint foreign affairs and defence committees very little attention has been given to trade. I am not saying that that is right. It is my view, and I think it is the view shared by most of my colleagues, that trade is an intrinsic part of foreign affairs. But as a term of reference trade is a quite separate issue for a committee. It ought to be tied more to industry and commerce. It seems to me that there is no logical reason for having the committees constituted in their present form.

When I look at the terms of reference previously in existence but not concluded I see that under the allocation of terms of reference to the new committees `the potential of the Kakadu National Park region'-in fact the wrong words have been used; the term of reference given in October 1985 was `the potential resources of the Kakadu National Park'-has been given to the Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee. This reference was previously inquired into by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources-an obvious choice because it examined the resource potential of Kakadu. It also looked at tourism, but essentially the mainstream thrust of the inquiry was to examine the potential of the Kakadu National Park with respect to uranium, gold and its other resources. Logically, that term of reference ought to stay with a committee which has those general interests. After many months and thousands of pages of evidence, that reference has reached its concluding stages. No doubt the members of the Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee will in no way be the same senators, either some of them or all of them, who were on the National Resources Committee. The Government will have to start that Committee's inquiry all over again if it is to do the job properly and provide a comprehensive report to the Parliament. I say to Senator Ray that what we have received from him by way of concession is modest when we look at the bottom line in terms of the functioning of the committees. It begs the question of logic and of how much concern the Government has for the committee system.

TALK.START.PARA: —You tell them what the logic is.

—I am asking him to explain the logic of this. It seems to me that the logic is that it is intended to fit comfortably with government departments and the super-ministries and the Ministers with responsibility. It is not in any way designed to serve the interests of the Senate. It is designed to serve the benefits of government and not the Parliament. It is a prostitution and an abuse of power and a destruction of the committee system.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In place of the old standing order 38, which has now been removed, I wish to move my amendment to insert new standing order 38. This matter has been canvassed many times in the Senate. We do need a more systematic consideration of which Bills should be referred to committees. I am aware that both the Government and the Australian Democrats are not prepared to support this amendment, so I merely put on record that this is the view of the Opposition as to what an appropriate procedure should be for the orderly consideration of which Government Bills would benefit from being considered by Senate committees. In the circumstances I do not propose to force this matter to a division. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Insert new Standing Order 38, as follows:

`38. (1) A Standing Committee, to be known as the Selection Committee on Bills, shall be appointed to consider all Bills introduced into the Senate or received from the House of Representatives, except Bills which contain no provisions other than provisions appropriating revenue or moneys, and to report:
(a) in respect of each such Bill, whether the Bill should be referred to a Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee; and
(b) in respect of each Bill recommended for referral to a Standing Committee:
(i) the Standing Committee to which the Bill should be referred,
(ii) the stage in the consideration of the Bill at which it should be referred to the Standing Committee, and
(iii) the day which should be fixed for the Standing Committee to report on the Bill.
`(2) The following provisions shall apply to the Committee:

(a) the Committee shall consist of the Government Whip, the Deputy-Government Whip, the Opposition Whip, the Australian Democrat Whip and one Senator nominated by the Chairmen of the Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees;
(b) the quorum of the Committee shall be 3 members;
(c) the Chairman of the Committee shall be the Government Whip, and the Deputy-Chairman shall be the Deputy-Government Whip; and
(d) in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, shall have a casting vote.
`(3) Where the Committee reports on any sitting day, the report shall be presented after the presentation of papers by Ministers pursuant to Sessional Order.

`(4) Following the presentation of a report by the Committee, the Chairman of the Committee, or a member of the Committee on behalf of the Chairman, may move without notice a motion, in accordance with a recommendation of the Committee, that a Bill, at the conclusion of any stage of the consideration of the Bill, stand referred to a Standing Committee.

`(5) Following the disposal of any motions moved in accordance with paragraph (4), a Senator may move without notice a motion to refer to a Standing Committee any Bill of the kind referred to in paragraph (1) which is not the subject of a motion moved pursuant to paragraph (4).
`(6) A motion moved pursuant to paragraph (4) or (5) shall specify:
(a) the Standing Committee to which the Bill is to be referred;
(b) the stage in the consideration of the Bill at which it is to be referred to the Committee; and
(c) the day on which the Committee is to report.

`(7) Upon a motion moved pursuant to paragraph (4) or (5), no Senator shall speak for more than 5 minutes, and at the expiration of 30 minutes, if the debate be not sooner concluded, the President shall put the Question on the motion and any amendments before the Chair.

`(8) Where a motion moved pursuant to paragraph (4) or (5) is agreed to, at the conclusion of the stage of the consideration of the Bill referred to in that motion the Bill shall stand referred to the Standing Committee referred to in the motion, and the further consideration of the Bill shall be an Order of the Day for the day fixed for the presentation of the report of the Standing Committee.

`(9) In considering a Bill referred to it pursuant to this order, a Standing Committee shall have no power to make amendments to the Bill or requests for amendments, but may recommend amendments or requests for amendments which would be in order if proposed in a Committee of the Whole.

`(10) A report from a Standing Committee relating to a Bill referred to it under this order shall be received by the Senate without debate, and consideration of the report deferred until the Order of the Day relating to the Bill is called on.
`(11) When the Order of the Day relating to a Bill which is the subject of a Standing Committee report pursuant to this order is called on, the following procedures shall apply:
(a) a motion may be moved without notice that the report of the Standing Committee be adopted;

(b) if a motion under subparagraph (a) is moved, following the disposal of that motion a motion may be moved by a Minister, or, in respect of a Bill introduced into either House of the Parliament other than by a Minister, by the Senator in charge of the Bill, that consideration of the Bill be an Order of the Day for a future day, or that the Bill not be further proceeded with;

(c) if no motion under subparagraph (a) or (b) is agreed to, a motion may be moved without notice that the Bill again be referred to the Standing Committee for reconsideration, provided that such motion:
(i) indicates the matters which the Standing Committee is to reconsider, and
(ii) fixes the day for the further report of the Standing Committee;

and if such motion is agreed to the Bill shall stand referred to the Standing Committee, and the further consideration of the Bill shall be an Order of the Day for the day fixed for the presentation of the further report of the Standing Committee; and

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed standing order 300a addresses the problem of joint committees and Senate committees being permitted to meet while the Senate is in session. The attitude of the Opposition is that this practice should not be permitted. As a result, we would like to oppose proposed standing order 300a. However, the Opposition feels that if the Senate is of the view that committees should be permitted to hold private sessions while the Senate is sitting, at the very least an amendment should be made to make it quite clear that votes cannot be taken in the absence of committee members on their proper Senate duties.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I am not quite sure how you would like to handle this. Our initial position is that we oppose completely new standing order 300a. I would like to be given an assurance that if the proposed standing order is agreed to, I will be given leave to move my amendment to proposed standing order 300a. Mr President, would that be acceptable to the Senate? Our first position is that we would like to oppose the proposed standing order altogether. But if that fails, we would like to amend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make the attitude of people on this side of the Senate very clear on this matter. The initial proposition was to allow committees to meet while the Senate was meeting; that is, to allow public hearings-the lot. I suppose, as a concession, we could cut it back to private sessions. If we want to be truthful about this, we would admit that Senate committees meet in private session while this Senate is meeting. This practice is a breach of Standing Orders and I think it puts a very unfair burden on both the Presiding Officer and his assistants at the table in terms of trying to enforce that standing order. Committees quite often meet because they might have only half an hour's discussion to go. They cannot always fit such discussions into a lunch time or, if they can, the meeting trickles over to 2 o'clock and a legal meeting suddenly becomes illegal.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me irresponsible on many occasions for those committees which actually take up responsibility never meet while this chamber meets, to have to fly everyone, including Senator Crichton-Browne-and we all know about his famous trip from Perth to Canberra, at $1,000 a go--

TALK.START.PARA: —And $1,300 return.

—And $1,300 return every time just to have private hearings. One of two things happen: either the standing order is breached or committees have an unofficial meeting at which members of the committee get together. Let us say that a committee's unofficial meeting starts at 11 a.m. and goes right through to 12.45 p.m. The moment that 12.45 p.m. is reached, the committee has an official meeting and everything that it has done in the previous hour and three-quarters is ratified. This standing order really should be enforced or the Opposition should support the proposition that we have put up.

SPEECH.PARA: Four Government members and four non-Government members will comprise most of the committees. So one does not have to make a meal out of it on most occasions. There should generally be enough senators to vote to ensure that this proposed standing order is used only as often as it is needed. I come back to an earlier point which was made by Senator Macklin. If this proposal does not work, clearly there are enough numbers on all sides of the chamber to have this standing order changed again. In other words, it is undesirable to have all the committees having their private sessions while this chamber is in session. All we seek to do is to give committees the right-hopefully this right will be used only occasionally-to complete their hearings, especially when they are right at the end of their reports.

We are not arguing for public hearings to be held while the Senate is sitting. Anyone who attended the Murphy hearings would know that it would be impossible for this chamber to operate correctly if public hearings are held while the Senate is sitting. I hope that we are not about to say that everyone sits in this chamber at all times and that everyone is available at all times. One only had to look at the size of the audience when Senator Teague spoke earlier to know that we do not always have enthusiastic senators here listening to every word. Indeed, it is rather unusual that we have so many honourable senators here at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it is you.

—I do not think so, Senator Ryan. Whilst we have been willing to try to accommodate, help and get consensus on this issue, we feel fairly strongly that previously Standing Orders have been honoured more in the breach than the observance and we might as well make it legal. I say again, in conclusion: if committees make a meal of it and have all their private hearings while the Senate is in session, it is entirely open to honourable senators to come back and to oppose and change the Standing Orders or, as they are now, the Sessional Orders, in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond to the Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray), who suggested that I am going to spend 12 hours in an aeroplane just to come to a brief private meeting. The Minister misunderstands, either accidentally or purposely, the proposition that I put. There is no reason at all that one cannot have private meetings during the sitting week when the Senate is not sitting. There is nothing to prevent one having private meetings either immediately before or immediately after public hearings when the Senate is not sitting. It is not a question of flying long distances; it is not a question of forming in non-sitting weeks; it is a question of functioning while the Parliament is sitting outside the houses or adding private meetings on to public meetings. I have been on a number of Senate standing committees, Senator Ray, I do not know which ones the honourable senator is attached to, but I do not recall--
—None at the moment.

—Bless you. I do not recall one occasion on which I have attended a private meeting when the Parliament has been sitting. We have always been able to so arrange our affairs as to ensure that we have had private meetings immediately before or after public hearings, or after hours if a short meeting is required.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem I see with the Government's proposition is that it will become the norm very quickly and not the exception, and out of convenience senators will find themselves sitting regularly in private meetings when the Parliament is sitting. The Minister has put it to us that if that becomes the case, if a meal is made of it-to use his words-we can come back and try again. I say to the Minister, with respect, that we are saying now that we are opposed to it. Coming back in a fortnight's time is not going to change a thing. The Minister is not going to change his mind because the proposal suits him. The Minister says to me, `Come back if it does not work'. I do not know what he means by the words `if it is does not work'. Under his criteria the proposals to have the vast majority of private meetings when the Parliament is sitting will work admirably. This practice will detract from the contribution that honourable senators make in this chamber; it will detract from the contribution they try to make elsewhere; and it will detract from the general level of debate and contribution in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate on behalf of the Australian Democrats that we will be supporting the proposition to allow committees to sit in private session during the sittings of the Senate. During the last Parliament I was a member of six committees. Quite frankly, I found that admirable co-operative arrangements were entered into by the members of all of those committees as to when we would sit. One of the first things that the members of all of the committees of which I was a member did when we met was to get out our diaries and try to work out when we could sit the next time.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators know that there are many occasions on which committees do not in fact have meetings as such. We all get into a room, go through all of the business and then, when the Senate rises, we have a quick meeting to ratify everything that we have done. Quite frankly, that seems to me to be a slightly absurd way of operating. We know what goes on and we know what has to happen. The time of senators is simply coming increasingly under pressure. I would have thought that the least we would do was to attempt to streamline some of the operations. I must admit that my Party proposes that I be a member of four committees, rather than the six, and thank goodness for that. Because I pick up a number of portfolio areas for my Party in this chamber, I do not very much relish the thought of sitting in committees while the chamber is sitting.

Nevertheless, I think we can get some of the necessary items out of the way. One can often fit in another meeting. Last night was a good example-although possibly not, because by 10.30 p.m. the speakers' list had collapsed. But up to that point there had been a fairly good indication, even before dinner, of who would be speaking at what time until 10.30. If members of a particular committee did not appear on that speakers' list and if that committee needed to get through some business in a hurry prior to a public inquiry, that would have been an admirable opportunity to do so. Let us offer that opportunity.

I am quite sure that senators who serve on those committees are all reasonable people. If there are senators who object to meeting at that time and if there is sufficient objection I am quite sure those committees will not meet. I have always found that there is very little problem and that committees generally try to operate to meet the requirements of all the senators who are members, not just the majority. The types of problems that Senator Hamer raised related to votes. Indeed, if I were on a committee that sought to take a vote while I was on chamber duty or unavailable for some other reason, I would think that that was a very odd committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —All the Opposition has to do is keep calling quorums.

—I am sure it would not do that; I am sure it would not be needlessly obstructive. I am sure that those committees, comprising sensible adults working sensibly together, can always come to an amicable arrangement about when the vote will be taken, if there has to be a vote. In my seven years of serving on Senate committees, I must admit that I have not found the types of problems that have been outlined. Let us give it a go. If we run into problems and if the committees do the types of things that Senator Hamer suggested-and that is the major objection-then obviously we come back to this place and change it. Until that time let us give it a try and see whether we can make things a little more efficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to this debate, what is obviously very clear is that everybody here is after the same goal. We all want to see the tax rorts and the welfare cheats done away with. Nobody would disagree that this is what must be done. The Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, in her second reading speech introducing the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3], said:

SPEECH.PARA: Honest Australians should not be subsidising those who are operating dishonestly within the tax and welfare systems. Honest Australians have a right to expect Government to protect the community as a whole from fraud and abuse against the tax and welfare systems. They have a right to expect that the Government ensures as best as it can that everyone contributes their fair and reasonable share of tax. They have a right to expect that welfare benefits are paid only to those who are truly entitled to those benefits.

I do not think that anybody in this chamber could possible disagree with those statements. So the question in hand is: How can we best achieve that? When the Australia Card was first thought up as a way to combat tax fraud and social welfare cheating in 1985, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) put out a White Paper which contained the germ of the idea. This was entitled `Reform of the Australian Taxation System'. But what has happened is that the idea has gone overboard, so to speak. We do not want to be a country like South Africa and in trying to have some controls cause imprisonment without trial. We do not want to throw the baby out with the bath water, so to speak. There is a very easy way to cure a headache; that is, to cut your head off. But I do not think anyone would suggest that that is the best cure for a headache.

There are many oddities in this Bill that I would like to discuss. The first oddity is that, if it comes to fruition, the Australia Card will be administered by the Department of Community Services and Health. That is typical of the rather muddled thinking that is being proceeded with in the attempt to achieve these goals. Once the idea of an identification card had been mooted, the Government agreed to the establishment of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card to look at all the possibilities. The Committee had eight members, from both Houses and from all parties. The Committee examined 129 submissions and many witnesses and took a great deal of evidence, which was just about measured in tonnes. In May 1986 the Joint Select Committee reported to the Parliament. The Committee did not want the Australia Card, according to its majority report. On the evidence collected the majority said no. I remind honourable senators that the evidence included the Government's own 300-page submission, `Towards Fairness and Equity', as well as the Health Insurance Commission's final planning report. This report is rather like a telephone directory. It contains all the possible ways of administering an ID card, with some colour plates in it of what it might look like, with photograph, without photograph, adults, children, resident, visitor and so on. But the majority of the Committee still said no.

The majority consisted of Liberals James Porter and Senator Chris Puplick, National Party Charles Blunt, John Saunderson from the Australian Labor Party and Democrats Leader Senator Janine Haines. The majority represented all parties, including the Government's Party. Three members of the Committee, all ALP members, put in a dissenting minority report: Senator Terry Aulich, Bob Brown and John Brumby. The Committee, which said no to the ID card, did, however, make a number of recommendations. It recommended a computerised register of births and deaths which should be restricted to a few government departments, notably the Australian Taxation Office. The Committee recommended the establishment of a data protection agency to control the collection and use of personal data. Above all, it recommended that the Government introduce a series of measures, which are generally referred to as option B and which relate to ranking and taxation and an upgraded tax file number. This was felt by the Committee to be necessary to combat tax and social security fraud.

The Committee proposed that the use of the tax file number be extended to cover all the financial transactions proposed in the Government's submission for use of the Australia Card number by the Australian Taxation Office as well as for social security purposes. It is most unfortunate that Senator Ryan in her speech should describe this as the shoddy alternative. I do not think that a parliamentary select committee from both Houses should have its solution termed the shoddy alternative.

The Committee also decided that Medicare should continue as a separate entity with a separate numbering system. The problem here, as would be the problem with the proposed Australia Card, is one of low integrity documents. Birth certificates as issued now are low integrity documents. Even with option B, tax file numbers would have to be investigated over a period of years. But this could be done. The Committee's recommendation was that it should take about five years and that the Department of Social Security should progressively review proof of identity of all existing pension and unemployment benefit beneficiaries to bring them within the system of controls based on tax file numbers.

It is very important to note that at this stage the Committee had not seen the proposed legislation, the Australia Card Bill, as it stands now. It simply did not exist. The Government had the idea of the card and set up the Select Committee to look at the options. But then it ignored the Committee's recommendations and went ahead with the card anyway. The Bill was introduced into the other place. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) gave the second reading speech in October last year. The Bill was then defeated in this place. When it was defeated the second time, in December last year, it nominally became the trigger for the Federal election. But we all must admit that it really was not an issue during the election campaign. It was not a campaign issue at all. I would like to ask why the Government was so silent on the issue during the election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister announced it.
—Yes, but as an election campaign issue it was not a hot issue, shall we say.
—Ask the Opposition why that was the case.
