—The Opposition was also quiet, I agree. So were the media. The media were very blase about the whole subject. The Democrats certainly tried to raise the issue. In our Party's national journal we carried a major article on why we opposed the card, written as early as December last year. Time and again during the election campaign the Democrats Leader Janine Haines spoke out against the Australia Card, particularly on talkback radio, all over Australia asking the hard questions about the card. Those questions were: `Is it necessary?', `Is it a threat to civil liberties?' and `Will it work?'. But as I said, the issue did not get picked up. The ID card did not become a hot election issue. Because of that I ask: does the Government really have a mandate, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Ryan claim? The issue certainly was the trigger for the double dissolution, but what actually is a mandate?

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has a mandate to govern according to its published policy platform. The Government has a mandate not to reintroduce tertiary fees. The Government has a mandate to introduce land rights. The Government has a mandate not to sell uranium to the French. But I do not believe that the Government has a mandate to impose numbers on the Australian people, to bulldoze legislation through the Parliament or to ignore the clear wish of the majority of Australians with the thin promise that the legislation will be amended after it has been passed.

As I said in my inaugural speech only yesterday, democracy functions only if the electorate understands what is going on. I do not believe that the electorate understood the full implications of the proposed Australia Card legislation. The details of the Bill were not spelt out to the electorate. Most people also thought-I have spoken to a number of people about this-that once the Bill was defeated that would be the end of it, even if it caused a double dissolution. Out in the electorate people just did not understand the full implications of the double dissolution and of a proposed joint sitting of both Houses of Parliament.

The Constitution says that, in the event of a joint sitting, the same Bill which was used as a trigger for the election has to be used. In other words, the Bill cannot now be amended. We cannot even take out its more objectionable parts. It is a straight yes or no situation, take it or leave it. We cannot change the Bill at all. I hope that we can try to change the minds of Government senators so that the Bill can be referred to a Senate committee of inquiry.

Honourable senators will recall that the original Joint Committee never actually studied the legislation. Until recently, when we started to publicise the details of the Bill, members of the general public had no real idea of the consequences of the proposed law. There is no doubt that people are changing their minds. One has only to look at the polls reported in today's Australian. In June 1986 the total number of people in favour of the Australia Card was 68 per cent, as polled. But in September 1987 the number was down to 39 per cent. In June 1986 the people who believed that we should have no identity card at all numbered 29 per cent of the population. By September 1987 this had risen to 57 per cent. That is a remarkable increase and it must reflect a change in public opinion since the details of the Bill have been made public.

When the Bill was first introduced a few law students and people in civil liberties organisations, some, but not all, Australian Democrats and quite a few people who had come to Australia from left or right wing totalitarian states objected to the card, but now this objection has snowballed as people start to look at the whole thing. Public meetings have been held all over Australia. An organisation in Western Australia called `People Against the Australia Card' held a meeting in the South Perth Civic Centre. More than 2,000 people turned up. The hall seated only about 600 to 700 people, which meant that some people were standing up around the sides and in the foyer and even outside in the car park. This has been the pattern throughout Australia. There have been newspaper editorials against the card. Trade unions, first in South Australia and now everywhere, and Labor lawyers provide all the traditional support that the Government usually relies on, but that support is slowly slipping away. I appeal to Government senators to listen to what is going on, to listen to the community and to realise that people do not want this draconian legislation.
The Government claims that the Australia Card is being introduced to combat tax fraud and social security fraud, but unfortunately this legislation goes much further than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—I will come to that in a moment, Senator. Mr Hawke said on the Willesee show that he would amend the ID card legislation, when passed, if it were to the benefit of people. That is an admission that this legislation should be changed before rather than after the event. There is another problem in that statement made by Mr Hawke. If the card can be amended to the advantage of the people after it has been passed, it can also be amended to their disadvantage.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that we are all here to represent ordinary people. At least I feel that I am, and I presume that the Government senators feel the same way. For the most part, ordinary people are fair and willing to pay their fair share of tax and do not want to cheat the welfare system. They are willing to see that tax and welfare cheats are brought to justice. The problem is that the Australia Card will not necessarily do that. The Government says that it will, but a vast number of people in the community are not so optimistic. Computer societies around Australia are also unhappy with the card. Senator Nick Bolkus, who should be on the Government's side, wrote a penetrating paper on the Australia Card in which he demonstrated that, far from making tax fraud harder, the card would make it easier. It is telling commentary on the way the Government functions that Senator Bolkus has been rather silent on the issue ever since.

The Health Insurance Commission has admitted that more than 20,000 duplicate Medicare cards have been issued and that many have been used to defraud the Department of Health. In a recent Four Corners program on Australian Broadcasting Corporation television, Frank Costigan, QC, the man who gave his name to the royal commission investigating tax fraud, stated that the problem was simply not one of identification. He said that tax fraud is a matter of clever operators finding loopholes, setting up bogus companies and operating at the bottom of the harbour. An ID card is not going even to touch the big operators. Neal Blewett, in his second reading speech on the Bill, said:

I would urge members of both Houses to read the Bill with care, and not to reject it on the basis of a Luddite distrust of technology, or on the basis of unexamined assumptions about the threat to privacy.

But far from having a Luddite distrust of technology, it is because we and the computer organisations understand the possibilities of technology that we distrust it. That is why computer experts such as Professor Jennifer Seberry distrust it. At the recent Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference Professor Seberry said:
It is frightening just how little security exists to protect computer data from the curious . . .

She said that the Australia Card could lead to an unprecedented invasion of privacy. So much for the Government's stance that the innocent have nothing to fear. As the Law Council of Australia argued in its submission to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card:
Honest people would remain honest but encumbered by the card; dishonest people will remain so-unaffected by the card, yet having it available as an additional tool.
It is precisely the innocent who have the most to fear and who can be manipulated.

I now turn to Senator Beahan's point. Nobody objects to having an identity-to being someone. Most of us do not object to carrying cards associated with that identity. We all have Bankcards, library cards and driving licences and taxpayers all have, or should have, a tax file number. But where the Australia Card legislation goes overboard and far beyond any of these other cards, is that it links all the information into one great computerised centre. There will be one number for each citizen, and that number will give access to the citizen's tax records, health records, the date of marriage, birth and death and address and occupation of the citizen. At the moment there are 35 separate bits of information proposed for the central databank on each citizen. But the legislation is open-ended. More can be added as the Government requires. Who has access to all of this information? A whole army of bureaucrats from different Government departments have access and, after that, it is anybody's guess.

I recently spoke to a person who used to work in the Taxation Office, but I am happy to say that he does not work there now. He said that the first thing he did when he started work there was to look up all the taxation records of his friends, just out of curiosity and with no malice in mind, and he was able to do that quite easily. I put it to honourable senators that bureaucrats will automatically have access to information to which they have no right.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have now.

—Yes, but at least there is no cross-referencing. At least the taxation records are limited to taxation. That is the whole point. Senator Ryan has repeatedly claimed that the system will be secure. I refer her to the computer section of today's Australian for an account of how enthusiastic and sophisticated amateurs in West Germany had three months access to the supposedly secure National Aeronautics and Space Administration network in nine countries. I put it to honourable senators that Senator Ryan's secure system would provide an exciting challenge to hackers. I wonder how long it would take them to crack the code. Yet the greatest danger to the security of the system is, as I have just said, probably the small army of public servants who would have some legitimate access to the system.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention a subtle but important philosophical point. Under our free democratic system, a person is presumed innocent until proven guilty. The onus of proof is on the state. Yet the ID card proposal effectively reverses this presumption. Here I am, a free person in a free society, and I do not need a card to tell anyone that I am a free and and innocent citizen. Let me quote from a recent editorial in the Australian Financial Review. It is a fairly unlikely ally, perhaps, but its editorial of 28 August made some very important points:

There is no requirement in Australia that anyone follow a particular religion or even a particular style of government other than one which is obviously subversive of a free system. Yet it is all too obvious that even today various authorities and police forces hold different views. The notion of `freedom' is not really well entrenched in this country, let alone given legal protection. If Australia's social freedoms become established around a formal `identity card', it is hard to believe that they will not be weakened.
The Australian Financial Review went on:
The role of a self-styled reformist government such as that led by Mr Hawke should be to reinforce the bulwarks of democracy and not to destroy them.
It is simply obscene to use revenue arguments (`we can make more money out of the Australia Card') as support for authoritarian impositions rather than take the road of broadening national freedoms.

Very well then, but would it work? Some people might argue that we have to give up some of our freedoms in order to live in a reasonable society-we all drive on the same side of the road, we conform to all sorts of rules and regulations-but would the centralised databank actually have an effect on tax fraud? Well, have a look at some of the countries which have something of the sort-Sweden, and Italy and other European Economic Community countries. The black market in Italy is estimated to be between 30 per cent and 50 per cent of that country's economy. It just flows around the official, regulated market. The same is true in the rest of Europe. In Sweden, where the databank system is most sophisticated, and which the Australian Government is looking at as a model, there are further and darker ramifications. The Swedish black economy is thriving but, at the same time, so is the level of electronic snooping by the Swedish Government. That country's databank agency was established with the same sort of optimism as Neal Blewett has when he talks about the Australia Card. But quite recently, Jan Freese, the Chairman of the Swedish Data Inspection Board, actually resigned from the Board because of what he saw as a serious misuse of the collected information. He was deeply pessimistic, he said, about a `computerised future' and the existing abuse of interlinked information systems. This was the system, remember, which is the model for the proposed Australian system.

If one tries to find out about the card itself, the actual piece of plastic, one comes across a curious vagueness. There is something called the Australia Card Secretariat, attached to the Department of Community Services and Health. But my understanding is that no actual work on the administration of the card took place after the first defeat of the Bill last year. There are various mock-ups in various Government reports. There are also some worrying reports of a so-called `smart card', which is a wholly different can of electronic worms.
Right at the beginning of the Bill it is stated that no one is compelled to carry the card. But, to quote Neal Blewett:
If people wish not to carry a card, they'll just have to recognise they will have that particular inconvenience . . .

What sort of inconvenience? Under clause 49 (2) it is an offence for an employer to pay a non-card-carrying person; under clause 49 (1) a cardless person may not be hired anyway. Widows and the sick, supporting parents, the aged and invalids cannot expect to be paid their pensions or benefits without a card. Under clause 40 (2) cardless citizens will not be able to get at their own bank accounts; or have access to money in a trust or other financial institutions; or sell or rent a house; or claim Medicare benefits; or perhaps even receive hospital treatment. All of this is in the name of tax fraud. This is why I say that this legislation has gone overboard. And remember that the Bill states that no one will be compelled to carry the card-that is, if they do not mind the inconvenience of becoming a non-person in their own country, not being paid through their bank accounts and not receiving social security benefits.

`Strange bedfellows' is a political cliche. We do not all oppose the Australia Card for the same reasons, but in this chamber we are all in very good company. The card is opposed by honourable senators from three political parties and, I believe, the independents as well. Only the Australian Labor Party's rigid and undemocratic Caucus system prevents us counting among us many on the Government side of the chamber who are on record as being privately opposed to the Bill but who will not buck the system.

Finally, I would just like to add that 200 years ago the First Fleet brought 1,000 people to Australia in chains. But these people were in iron chains which could be struck off with a hammer, and they were. Australia became a free nation of free citizens. But the chains imposed by the Australia Card are more subtle. They will entrap a whole nation, and no one knows where the captive nation will be led in future. All we know is that the new chains have been forged by a deceit. I do not believe that it has been deliberate; nonetheless, I believe that that deceit is there. In the past many of us have taken up the struggle against wrong laws. We have taken up the struggle in the streets and taken it to the people. We have protested at the Vietnam war, blockaded the Franklin River, and we have walked against war. I certainly support the amendment that has been moved. I say: let this Australia Card legislation go before a Senate committee of inquiry; let the debate continue; let it be put to a referendum of the people of Australia. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Puplick. We have heard very little in the Government's case, such as it has been, for this piece of legislation, about either the costs of the measure or the benefits purported to flow from it. Yet, it is that narrow financial calculation which the Government presents as being the basic justification for the introduction of what I refrain from calling the Australia Card-the ID card. We on this side of the chamber certainly do not accept that, even if it were possible to justify the claim that there is a valid cost-benefit ratio for this particular measure, that in itself would justify its introduction. We happen to believe that there is a great deal more to matters of this grave kind than mere dollars and cents.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us, nevertheless, address the proposition first on the ground which the Government itself chooses-namely, those dollars and cents. The Government has, so far as I am aware, produced no basis for its estimates of the cost of this measure. Indeed, it is not altogether easy to ascertain what those costs are estimated to be. One sees figures in the order of three-quarters of a billion dollars floating around over some indeterminate period-something like the next four to five years. We see equally cloudy estimates of the asserted financial benefits, which seem to change almost whenever the Treasurer (Mr Keating) rewrites his Budget Speech.

I think it has recently been claimed by the Treasurer that the benefits will amount to no less than $1 billion a year once the scheme is in full swing. In any case magnitudes of that kind are not being compared on a like basis because the stream of benefits alleged to flow from this measure is not being converted-at least as far as I am aware; I have seen no calculations of this-into present values, nor is the stream of costs. Until both those things are done one cannot actually compare them on a like to like basis. Apart from the fact that that elementary-rudimentary, one might have thought-estimate is not offered to us, we have no details. As far as I am aware we have had no details whatsoever on either the cost side or the benefit side. We have had no detail as to how much the introduction of this card, when fully operative-years ahead of us-will garner by way of additional revenue-and that is the key point-over and above what would otherwise be obtained from the normal operation of the taxation system from income taxes on individuals or company taxes or, indeed, from any other source.

On the other aspect of the alleged financial benefits of this measure, equally we have seen no estimates in any way broken down of the gains or savings to be had on the expenditure side of the Budget as a result of the introduction of this card from the minimisation or reduction of those whom this Government only 18 months ago was refusing to call `dole bludgers'. The Government now seems to have discovered dole bludgers and it seems to believe that it has them coming out of its ears. Nevertheless, it is totally reluctant to give us any figures as to the savings that it, or the government of the day, might obtain from that quarter. As far as I know, the Government has given no details of the savings-additional savings over and above those that might otherwise be obtained by normal administrative measures-from the area of the supporting parent's benefit. It has given no estimate of the savings to be had in the areas of sickness benefits or invalid benefits. Indeed, we have no detail whatsoever for these totally unsupported figures which, on the face of it, the Government appears to have plucked largely out of thin air.

When senators on this side of the chamber have made their now considerable objections known to this measure, some Government senators-not all have been so dishonourable-have had the impertinence to allege that people arguing as we have argued are guilty of supporting tax rorts and welfare cheats. I know of no more discreditable line of argument than that. I certainly do not convict all or even most Government senators of that line of dishonourable argument, but certainly some have been guilty of it. It is only proper to say, speaking for myself and, I am sure, for everyone on this side of the chamber, that opposition to this measure has nothing to do with sympathy for tax or welfare cheats. It has to do with a totally proper regard for the invasion of civil liberties which this measure principally represents.

Apart from that aspect, there is another aspect to this whole question of the Government's lack of estimates in this area. Such estimates as we have had from the Government-figures plucked largely out of thin air-are themselves considerably dated. In one breath the Government continues to say that it requires the introduction of the ID card in order to obtain these additional savings in the tax system, for example, but at the same time it is claiming-and with some substance, one must say-to have made great strides in already tightening up the administration of the tax system and in other ways garnering revenue that had not been obtained previously. In the past few years we have had the introduction of the prescribed payments system. That was introduced before I left the Treasury. We have had the introduction of the fringe benefits tax and the introduction of non-deductibility of legitimate business expenses for entertainment. We have had on an increasing basis-and it is promised to increase further-the audit system in the Australian Taxation Office, the introduction of the self-assessment processes and the diversion-I think perhaps long overdue-of a large portion of the Commissioner of Taxation's staff into audit procedures rather than assessment procedures. As we know from both the anecdotal evidence and much evidence in the journals of opinion, a good deal of success is being achieved in those areas.

In addition on the welfare side, earlier this year the Government belatedly introduced what I call its `search and destroy' teams. These teams go out into areas of the community where the level of unemployment benefit claimants appears to be abnormally high. They investigate the claimants in those areas. On the basis of the last figures I saw on that subject their strike rate-their kill rate, if you like-was something like 25 per cent of people who are being knocked off the unemployment benefit recipient rolls. I think I am also correct-in fact, I know I am-in saying that they are conducting similar `search and destroy' missions in the area of supporting parent's benefits. If one reads the Budget Papers-I am not making these matters up-which the Government produced only last week, one will find its claims for the savings being achieved in all these areas by these measures. This Government has been in office for four and a half years during which all these things have been going on. Only now has it got around to dealing with them. Yet this Government, far from reducing its estimates of financial benefits from the introduction of this card, has actually increased them. So much for that.

One has to ask why it is that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is so adamant-or appears to be so adamant-in the face of such mounting opposition, to introduce this ID card, this un-Australian card. I can only conclude that he is seeking to get the Australian people united, as for example, to choose a prototype at random, Bismarck did to Germany over a century ago. How he has succeeded. We have never seen Australians so united in their views. The trouble is, from the Prime Minister's point of view, that they are united against him, unlike the German people under Mr Bismarck. In this case the Prime Minister has shown some of the attributes of Bismarck of whom it was said that he had once declared that it was not by speechifying and majorities that the great questions of the time would have to be decided. In his memoirs Bismarck is said to have `fostered the impression of himself as a man of iron will, utter ruthlessness and studied purpose'. Perhaps we have seen some of those attributes coming to the fore in the Prime Minister's conduct in relation to the debate in and outside the Parliament on this un-Australian card. It is notable that anyone who dares to deny the Prime Minister's `iron will and studied purpose' in this regard is abused and denigrated.

We have seen a massive response, almost all of it adverse, to the un-Australian Card in all our major newspapers. The response has amazed even otherwise hard-nosed editors. I have chosen a letter from today's Australian as illustrating the kind of letter that is being written to our newspapers on this topic by people who do not normally write to the newspapers. I happen to know the author of the letter I am about to quote. The author is Mr Ewart Smith, who for many years was a colleague of mine in the Commonwealth Public Service. He was for many years, as long as I can remember, in fact, in the Attorney-General's Department of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is why he agreed to sign your letter.

—I will respond to that interjection, Madam Acting Deputy President, because it is typical of the quality of interjection coming from that quarter of the Senate-a new senator who perhaps has yet to learn better, and therefore I will not name him. Nevertheless, in the interjection the senator has slandered a man who has given probably 40 to 45 years service to this country in a manner which has certainly not yet been emulated and may never be emulated by the honourable senator opposite. He has chosen to suggest, through his interjection, that this honourable man has signed a letter which I drafted for him. I say no more, Madam Acting Deputy President. That kind of remark would normally be treated with contempt, but I thought it necessary to point it out as an example of the kind of interjection coming from that quarter of the Senate, which I think does the Senate no credit.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to my theme and continue with my remarks. Mr Ewart Smith, as I said, was for many years an officer of the Attorney-General's Department, rising to become a deputy secretary in that Department, a post which he held for 10 years. On his retirement from that Department he became for six years a member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, a position from which he has recently retired. He does not therefore speak from the position of ignorance of these matters which characterises the kinds of interjections coming from the Government benches. Therefore, I want to place on record one or two of the comments made by Mr Ewart Smith in his letter in this morning's Australian; he published a similar letter in the Canberra Times a couple of days ago. Mr Ewart Smith said:

Sir, I have never felt more strongly on any issue than the projected Australia Card. I am not, nor have I ever been, a tax cheat or a social security cheat . . . I have not engaged in any tax-avoiding family trust. Indeed, if I have an axe to grind, it is to seek the stopping of fraud.

After noting his service, which I have already enumerated to the Senate, Mr Ewart Smith said that in his capacity as an officer of the Attorney-General's Department he was a constitutional adviser to the government of the day:
. . . and enjoyed the confidence of the Liberal and Labor governments whom I served. I am not, nor have I ever been, a member of a political party.
But the time has come to speak out against this evil card. Those of us who served in the Second World War-
as he apparently did-
fought for freedom and that freedom must be jealously guarded . . . The price of liberty is eternal vigilance and never has our liberty been so threatened as at present.

The 130-page, 189-clause Bill that seeks to enmesh us all on the pretext that it is essential that we be properly identified to prevent tax fraud and social security fraud by a comparatively small proportion of society is an obscenity that must be stopped.
He goes on later in the letter to say:
The all-pervasive nature of the card system, apparent from a study of the Bill (which I have made)-
I cannot think of anyone more competent to make such a study-

will bring needless complication to all our lives and fear and worry to countless citizens (especially migrants), while sprinkling offences around like a fish-and-chips proprietor would with the salt.

I suppose that other senators' inward mail is rather like my own, reflecting the concerns of ordinary Australians. I received a letter today from which I propose to quote one paragraph only. This is from a Sydney medico, a woman whom I do not know very well but I know her well enough to know that she is a person of quality whose bona fides are not in question. She says:
Although I had not thought to write to you and Mr Hawke on one night, the sight of you walking the streets of Brisbane-
I think she must have seen the television footage of our anti-ID card demonstration there just over a week ago-

has prompted me to what must be every citizen's duty in opposing the imposition of the tyranny of the pernicious plastic card and the all-knowing data banks. It seems that 2,000 years of the supremacy of the individual over the domination of the state, in search of which so many have left lands of oppression, may yet hold sway in Australia. If not, at least I shall have added my invective to quell the arrogance of the coiffured puppet-
that is rather a harsh term to describe the Prime Minister-
who struts the stage and thinks himself untouchable.
She concludes the paragraph by quoting:
In order for evil to triumph it is necessary only that good men-
and she should have added `good women'-
do nothing.

What is this proposed law a law with respect to? Every Commonwealth law must be characterised as a law with respect to some subject of Commonwealth power conferred on the Commonwealth Parliament by the Constitution. We read in clause 3 of the Bill what its objects are. Taken at their face value, they appear to relate to the subject matters specified in the clause, which are undoubtedly Commonwealth powers. But are they to be taken at their face value? I ask: Is not the pith and substance of this proposed law rather a law to provide for the registration of the Australian people?

That was regarded as a valid exercise of the Commonwealth power during the Second World War. Everyone had to be registered under the national security regulations at that time, but when the war ended the power shrank accordingly. Are we now to be taken to be in a state of war? The Prime Minister just over 14 or 15 months ago suggested that we might be in a state of economic war, a statement which accords ill with his current euphoria over the Budget brought down last week. Nevertheless, are we taken to be in a state of war such that no one, for example, may operate his own bank account duly established before the `first relevant date', to use the term in the Bill, without producing an ID card, when he might have been known to his banker for perhaps 40 years? On the question of people being legally debarred from operating their own bank accounts without going through the procedures and processes laid down in this legislation, how dare the Government-how dare any government in Australia-legislate to deprive people retrospectively of access to their own assets in this manner.

The Bill is such an extensive product that it is not surprising that Government senators appear to be ill-informed about its contents. Indeed, one would have to say that the fact that it is such a wide-ranging document has meant that many people in the community have until recently been ill-informed about the detail of its contents. Consider only the processes related to the photographing of the Australian people which are laid down in the Bill. As I read the Bill, every person who has attained the age of 18 years is required to fill in a quite complicated application form and present himself or herself at an Authority office, an office of the Health Insurance Commission, for a photograph to be taken as required by the Authority. That is provided for in clause 12 (1) of the Bill. The mind boggles at the thought of upwards of 10 1/2 million people-that, I think, was about the number on the electoral roll at the last election-rolling up at the Authority's offices at the Authority's convenience-not the convenience of the people, of course, as that must take second place to the regimentation of the people. The Authority will not just ask them to come in to have their photographs taken. If that were done only about 20 per cent of them would come in to be branded. Not even an external passport system-I emphasise the word `external'-requires this sort of process. After all, if one wants to get an external passport in this country, one can bring one's own photograph so long as it is properly authenticated. But that is not the case with the Australia Card; people must learn to obey.

I suppose that one way to delay the legislation coming into force would be for everyone to object, under clause 12 (3) of the Bill, on some ground or other to having a photograph taken. For example, if only half of the 10 1/2 million people did this, what a grand shemozzle that would be. The objection could be based, for example, on the photographing being expected to cause-I quote from the relevant clause of the Bill-`an unreasonable amount of distress to the person or to a member of his/her family'. If 5 1/2 million people were to make such a claim, the Authority, and the Data Protection Agency, would have to go through the duly laid down procedures mentioned in division 4 of part VII of the Bill in relation to each of those 5 1/2 million objections and each decision on the objections.

I mentioned this matter to draw attention to the enormity of the problems and the way in which this legislation can be frustrated by determined people-and there are an awful lot of people out there who are very determined about this legislation at the moment, in case the Government has not yet noticed. Any such legislation of this conscription type demands, above all, consensus. It is the kind of legislation in respect of which, during a war, one may just possibly be able to achieve some kind of national consensus, although the history of conscription in Australia does not suggest that even in that case one is likely to be unduly successful. But certainly only in such times of extremes can one hope to achieve the kind of national consensus which is required to make legislation of this kind sufficiently acceptable to be operable. I am not talking now about principle; I am talking about the practical questions of bringing this thing into being. There is not only no consensus for the legislation; there is an overwhelming consensus against it. Just to round out this part of my remarks, I note that the photograph process will be repeated forever on a five-yearly basis.

The Government, and in particular the Prime Minister, are justifiably proud-at least I think the Prime Minister is-of our national anthem, Advance Australia Fair. Have they ever thought of the meaning of the words in the opening lines? In case they cannot remember them, let me repeat them for the benefit of Government senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you like to sing?
—They are:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's sons-
I am sure that would be an acceptable beginning for Senator Reynolds-
let us rejoice
For we are young and free

It is no accident that the word `free' appears in those opening lines-for that is what we have been, and it is in stark contrast to our old convict heritage. It was said of Britons that they `never, never, never shall be slaves'. That is what this legislation is about-enslaving us. How appalling it is, as our bicentenary year approaches, that Australians are once again having to fight for their freedom against a government which has been elected ostensibly to preserve it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Jenkins-I refer not to her speech this evening but to her maiden speech yesterday-I was told about the higher standard of debate in the Senate. Obviously, I came in at the wrong time if this debate on the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] is any example of the standards that are normal to this place. I was also told that the Senate is, in a sense, an orderly and predictable place, and last night I found that even that is not true.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the debate, even from the normally rigorous Senator Stone, has focused on the perceived depth of feeling in the community. Of course there is depth of feeling in the community. The depth of feeling is caused by the sort of debate that is occurring here and publicly outside. I refer to the hysterical outbursts that are being perpetrated by the Opposition and its partners in this campaign, the Australian Democrats. I refer to the sort of emotive language, bordering on hysteria, and the whipping up of fervour in the community so that it will oppose the card in a way in which it obviously did not during the election campaign, which was the reason that the Opposition did not fight the election on that issue at all. I refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 11 September by Alan Mitchell headed `The Crazies against the ID Card'. Referring to comments by Peter Garrett for example, the article says that the:
. . . `all-important numbering system' would give access to peoples' medical records, including treatment for sexually-transmitted diseases and psychiatric consultations.

It says further that Ben Lexcen `fears for the future of European Australia' and says that `he would be forced to leave the country'. Dr Shepherd apparently thinks it will start a civil war. Those sorts of statements along with others used in this House are the sorts of things that are stirring up this emotion and hysteria in the community, and it is no wonder that the position has changed since the election. I will argue that the position is coming back very slowly but very surely.

Examples of some of the emotive language that has been used in this place can be seen in the words of Senator Knowles. She referred to `dog tagging'. She went further to talk about tattooing on the forehead. Where in the Bill does she get that from? What item in the Bill gives any notion of that sort of totalitarian approach? Senator Michael Baume talked about the Hitler card or the Stalin card. Many people talk about the Moscow card. These are all attempts to link emotively very simple, straightforward and logical ideas to people's notions of what Hitler, Moscow or Stalin represent. Every rhetorical and propagandist trick is being used to stir up hysteria in the community, even to the point of gentle Senator Jenkins talking about this measure being reminiscent of the situation in South Africa and talking about imprisonment without trial. Where could she possibly get this out of this legislation? Who can tell me? The language is emotive; the arguments are at best subjective and at worst irrational and even absurd, and the imagery is simply florid, although it cannot be said to be very picturesque. So zealous is the campaign that even the media, which have been filling in during the interlude after the election when they have had nothing to write about, are starting to comment. Let me quote some of those media comments. I quote again from that same article by Alan Mitchell, `The Crazies against the ID Card':
But I don't understand what the other prominent opponents of the card-people like Peter Garrett and Dr Shepherd and Joan Coxsedge-
a nice motley group-
. . . find so terrifying. What is this extraordinary threat to privacy and liberty that might start a civil war or drive Ben Lexcen out of Australia?
In an article by Mike Steketee in the Sydney Morning Herald of 11 September headed `much ado about a host of wild misconceptions' he says, among other things:

For emotional claptrap, it is hard to go past the present debate on an identity card. There has seldom been a subject on which there has been so much misunderstanding, so much misrepresentation and so much downright irrational fear.

That irrational fear is the sort of thing that is being engendered by debates in this House and by those who express the same views at public meetings. I think that is quite wrong on the part of the Opposition and in particular on the part of the Australian Democrats, who pride themselves on a more rational approach. Members of the Liberal Party have a vested interest in upsetting the passage of this legislation no matter what their beliefs are, because it upsets the Government. The Democrats pride themselves on having some sort of sincerity, some sort of depth and some sort of analysis, but they are not showing it here.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Nationals?

—The National Party is as bad as the Liberal Party, and normally worse, if Senator Stone's contribution is any example. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald headed `The doubts about Australia Card' makes the following comment:

SPEECH.PARA: The fears of the identity card's more vociferous opponents sometimes verge on the neurotic.

That is another adjective that might apply to some of the things that have been said today and some of the people who have been saying them. In an article in the Age of 5 August 1987, headed `Card compatible with liberalism', Claud Forell says:

Of all the objections that can be raised against the proposed national identification scheme, the argument that it represents a threat to civil liberties of the honest individual seems to me to be the least convincing.
An article in the Australian of 5 September 1987 headed `In praise of the ``villainous'' ID card' makes the following point:

If totalitarianism depends on a plastic card, how did Hitler get as far as he did? More contemporaneously, how is the Soviet Union able to control its citizens in much the same way without one, either?
Because the means is being confused with the end. A totalitarian society can compile dossiers on its citizens with no trouble at all.
The card makes no difference. An article in the Daily Mirror of 10 August 1987 states:
The Australia Card may not be the perfect solution. But its opponents have not come up with anything better.

The media is turning. It is starting to look at the more rational side of the debate and to analyse the emotive and hysterical language being used by the Opposition. I believe that in time this debate will be turned around when people start to think about the issues in a less emotional way.

Senator Puplick's amendment defies logic in my opinion. It is based on the nonsense that we have not had enough time to debate the question. So we are to go into another committee, resulting in more words and a thick document, to debate the whole thing again. It has been debated ad nauseam. Let me remind honourable senators of the gruelling history of this legislation. As Senator Jenkins tonight reminded us-I will not go into the detail because she has it on record already-the concept was introduced in the draft White Paper entitled Reform of the Australian Taxation System in 1985 following estimates by the Australian Taxation Office that $3 billion was lost through tax evasion and that much of this was caused by the problem of identity.

The Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card was established in November 1985 and delivered its report in 1986 with, as has already been pointed out, a minority report. Agreement was reached in a number of areas. I think this needs to be recorded, because it seems to be conveniently forgotten by members of the Opposition and the Democrats. Firstly, it was agreed that tax evasion is widespread. It was agreed that there is a problem with welfare fraud. It was agreed that this is contributed to by the lack of a proper process of identification. It was agreed that the problem can and should be attacked by means of a unique numbering system. It was agreed that the current collection of statistics on births, deaths and marriages is inadequate and that there is a need for computerisation and a consequent need for Commonwealth assistance. It was agreed that the question of a unique numbering system raises civil liberties questions and that the Data Protection Agency should be set up. It was agreed-I think Senator Stone ought to look at the report once again, if indeed he has looked at it at all-that the net benefits of the schemes referred to by Senator Stone were underestimated. The whole Committee agreed that the benefits of the Australia Card or its counterpart, the tax file numbering system, were underestimates, not overestimates, despite what Senator Stone has said.

The only major dissension was over whether the unique numbering system should be in the form of a tax file number or in the form of an Australia Card. That was an important argument, but it was the only one. That seems to have been forgotten in this debate. The Government in response rejected the tax file number approach. I do not think Senator Ryan in her second reading speech was wrong when she referred to it as a shoddy alternative, even though Senator Stone objects to that description, because it is a lower integrity system and simply not as reliable-and there is no way of making it as reliable-as the Australia Card. As a result it has the potential for impersonation. In addition the cost benefit was found to be inferior. The estimated net revenue over a 10 year period from the tax file number approach was $1.6 billion. The estimated net revenue from the Australia Card was $4.7 billion. Finally, of course, the legislation was rejected twice and the Government went to the polls. I say that simply as a reminder, even though it is to repeat what Senator Jenkins has already said.

So the comments made by a number of honourable senators about not having time to canvass the issue are simply nonsense. Comments like those of Peter Garrett's in the Sydney Morning Herald of 11 September:

[The people] weren't told they will have to apply for the card, they weren't told about the all-important numbering system, about the storing of information on computers, about who will have access to it and who will guard it--

That is utter nonsense, as are the various accusations that have been made here about the time to debate it and the lack of information before the election. But even so, say the opponents-and Senator Jenkins made this point again tonight-the Government does not have a mandate. I refer to Senator Cook's contribution to this debate, recorded on pages 76 and 77 of the Hansard for Thursday, 17 September, in which he referred to the 7.30 Report. I will not go through that report because he quoted in detail the people interviewed. They are the country's top journalists. Let me summarise. All of these people agreed that the Government had a mandate. No one who participated in that program was in any doubt about whether the Government had a mandate. Geoff Kitney, Kerry O'Brien, Michelle Grattan, Greg Hywood and Laurie Oakes all thought that the Government had a mandate. I far prefer to go on the word of professional journalists of the nature of these people than to go on the letter of an individual expressing a personal point of view. I prefer that to the individual rantings of a person writing a personal letter to a newspaper. They are professional journalists making a judgment on an issue.
On the matter of the combined parties opposing the card gaining more votes than Labor, I shall do no more than quote Michelle Grattan, who said:

The claim that the Government does not have a mandate on the card because the conservatives and the Democrats were against it and they got more votes than Labor, is also a bit of nonsense. We cannot know what weight was given to the ID card in people's votes. Anyway, surveys showed a majority in favour of the card. The fact is the card was used as the Double Dissolution trigger. The Government was re-elected and, if it has a mandate for any measures, they include the ID card.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense logic. How can you argue one way and not the other?

—There is no nonsense in that logic. If the honourable senator can separate the issues in any election and say, `For that, you have a mandate; for that, you haven't; for this, you have, and for that you haven't', he is a better man than I am.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I can accept the fact that in the current climate, some people can feel emotional about the issue. It is not rational, but it is understandable. I do not suggest that everybody does it with the same sincerity. I was originally emotional on the issue of capital punishment. I have a strong aversion to that concept. It worries me greatly, just as it did before I became involved in politics. But it is incumbent on those people who start with an emotional view to develop a rational case to back it. I can now do that with capital punishment and argue the case against it cogently and rationally and adduce evidence to back my facts. Others might not agree with me but I can present my case rationally. No Opposition senator even bothers to do that because there is more in it for Opposition senators if they are emotional and hysterical. They whip up fervour in the community and get the whole campaign moving along. That is not good for Australia and is a poor thing for the standing of the Senate, which I was told was a much better place than the other House. There has been no attempt to adduce rational argument to back up emotional positions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's arguments appear to be exclusively of the `could be' or `might be' variety rather than the `is' or `likely to be' variety. The Opposition wants to look at the worst possible scenario because that is the best one to represent to the people to make the Government look worse. It is incumbent on Opposition senators to come up with a sensible and workable alternative. Despite what Senator Stone has said, if they do not they are de facto supporting the tax cheats and welfare frauds. They might not be in all sincerity personally supporting them, but de facto they are, and that is the important point.

The problem is too big to ignore. We cannot ignore the fact that so much money is being lost to the Treasury and that that is imposing a burden on honest people. There is much talk about rights and liberties. Of course that is important, but citizens, too, have a right to expect a taxation and welfare system which is fair and not subject to abuse, just as a car driver has a right to expect certain behaviour on the road so that he or she can drive safety home at night. To put it another way, does freedom mean the right to rip people off? That is what the current `freedom' which the Opposition defends so vehemently is all about. It is all about the right to rip people off and impose a greater burden on those people paying fair taxes-the majority.

From being an initial sceptic of the card and one who was a little concerned about its civil liberties aspects, I have come to the inescapable conclusion that the argument on civil liberties is, in the main, emotional nonsense. The same is true of the arguments on security. We have been using a variety of cards and numbering systems for years, as even Opposition senators have admitted. These include driving licences, credit cards, tax file numbers and Medicare cards. Most of them hold much more information than the Australia Card ever will, they have no controls over them and are not questioned by anybody. Despite the fact that over the years we have come to have all those cards, there is now a sudden fear. Methinks that sudden fear is a matter of a number of Opposition senators protesting too much. It does not sit comfortably and I do not think that it is genuine in most cases.

The argument about security goes to two aspects of the system-first, the transmission of storage and data and, secondly, the card. Senator Schacht alluded to safeguards in transmission and storage of data. He said that the data will be transmitted on landlines which cannot easily be broken into. I am not saying that one cannot break into the system but it would be a major task. He said that the material on the card will be encrypted, compressed and segmented and that one will not be able to make sense of the material even if one gets into it. Let us suppose that one of these hackers does all those things.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are plenty of them.

—There is no great evidence of that. But let us say there is a really bright operator who gets into the system. If he got through the major task of breaking into the code, he would find only a name, a digitised picture, a residential and postal address and a record of verifying information, plus some records on access to the card and reasons for it. To talk of that information being linked with all sorts of other agencies is nonsense. None of the other agencies can get more than that information. The Australia Card will have even less information than I have described.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me stress also that neither the card nor the Register will contain information on religion, marital status, family composition, employment or medical history, despite what Peter Garrett and some Opposition senators say. Furthermore, there will be no amalgamation of data. With the Data Protection Agency, there will be more protection for this scheme than there has been before. There is no protection now for the cards which we so glibly obtain and trust. Those cards are run by private industry, not by governments and public enterprises which do not have the same vested interest as private industry, yet we trust those systems. No one has thought about the fact that there is no protection for those systems. The Data Protection Agency will provide protection for the Australia Card and, ultimately, for a much wider net of stored information.

I am heartily fed up with the cant and gibberish which have accompanied this debate. It does little credit to those who espouse it. It does even less credit to the chamber. It is unbecoming of the Senate to reach that level of debate. I urge honourable senators in the interests of more sane debate to do two things-first, to up the level of their contributions, so that they deal with the real issues, and, secondly, to get this debate over now instead of shoving it off to another talkfest of a committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I lend my voice in opposition to the Australia Card-
—For the third time.

—Yes, for the third time. It is a most un-Australian Bill and card. I hope that Senator Beahan will not hear a lot of cant and gibberish from me. He has accused Opposition senators of being emotional and florid in our condemnation of the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3], yet the Australian Labor Party is trying to lull us into a sense of false security by telling us that this card differs little from all other cards, such as membership cards, credit cards, including Bankcard and American Express, and drivers licences, even those containing a photograph. But this card differs from all those. One honourable senator floundered on that difference and blamed it on the linkages. But that is not the case. It is the number that makes the difference. With all of those other cards the number belongs to the card. With the Australia Card the number belongs to you. That is an enormous difference. In other words `they' will know where you are. They will be able to establish an audit trail, follow whatever you do and wherever you go. In the language of the bureaucrats, you will become a `card subject' until you have your card and then when you get your card you will be an entity entitled to operate. But, if you can be an entity entitled to operate, you can also be an entity not entitled to operate. This is one of the great fears and why we have heard people described by honourable senators entering this debate tonight as non-people.

SPEECH.PARA: It has surprised me that the debate has always been on the pros and cons of the card, on whether it is any good or not and how well it will work or not work. The real debate ought to be on whether we have a card at all. This situation has arisen because of the gradual development of a welfare state and a welfare mentality in Australia. I suppose it has followed what has happened in the United Kingdom, which has again been as a result of governments promising more and more welfare in order to buy votes from the people. In order to provide more welfare one needs a bigger and bigger bureaucracy and the bureaucrats need more control. Finally, they have decided they want a card so that they can control us. In fact, I see the card as making a bureaucrats' valhalla. They want to know where you are, what you do, what you buy, what you sell, what you eat, what you drink and the presents you buy. I even saw in one of the analyses of this that they would even know if you bought a set of women's underclothes in a size different from your wife's when they could have been bought for your daughter. This could create problems.

We have heard a lot of talk about tax cheats and dole bludgers. But who is to say that the bureaucrats are such paragons of virtue anyway? They are ordinary people. I presume they have the same number of crooks amongst them as there are amongst the ordinary population. I know that they argue that they have stringent selection processes; but so do the police. That sort of argument has been put up before but it does not fill me with a lot of confidence. To get back to old Rome, the Romans were looking at putting more control on their people and they wound up with a saying, `quis custodiet ipsas custodes?'. That means: who is going to look after the looker-afterers? All of a sudden one finds that the looker-afterers are completely out of one's control. People may think that the Data Protection Agency and the committee advising it will protect us, but there is very little chance of that working. The Chinese have a proverb, `once two people know, it is no longer a secret'. That is very true because there is no way of guaranteeing the privacy of computers. It would be impossible to police the computers, even if all the information on them were correct. What if the information is wrong? Even if it is wrong by design, what is to stop a bureaucrat going on a fishing trip through one's affairs?

It has been mentioned in this debate that the Australia Card will turn our laws topsy-turvy. We operate under common law which has taken 2,000 years to develop from precedents. It is a basic principle of our law that one is innocent until proven guilty. If any authority wants to investigate someone, it has to get a search warrant and the search warrant has to be specific. In other words, it cannot go on a fishing expedition through all one's affairs. But, with the Australia Card, a bureaucrat will be able to go on a fishing expedition through one's affairs and he can do it without one's knowledge and without one's permission. That has been mentioned in the debate tonight. He can go through one's Medicare files. I have heard arguments from the Government that there will not be a big data bank that can be tapped. There does not need to be a big databank to be tapped; the data is in a whole lot of banks that may be remote from each other. It is quite possible to connect them up and get the information. It is wrong to say that they will be locked off from each other. Already they are being used in a way that I would say is illegal. A whole list of existing data banks-one's social security file, Medicare file, tax file and immigration file-can quite readily be tapped.

The Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, has given repeated assurances that the Health Insurance Commission's database is and will be secure for the purpose of the ID card. However, during the 1985 New South Wales doctors dispute, details of the Medicare incomes of prominent surgeons-notably Dr Bruce Shepherd who was mentioned here tonight-were revealed in a move calculated to discredit the surgeons' case in the dispute. The details were leaked from the Health Insurance Commission. There are abuses that the ID card will exacerbate. I cite the Dr McGoldrick case in which patients' medical records were targeted by the Health Insurance Commission and released to the police, who raided the doctor's surgery and took those cards away. They were then revealed to a court and used to procure witnesses without the patients' knowledge or consent. The patients were girls who were minors. It was all done in the public interest. Public interest is a reason often given for robbing people of their privacy and liberty.

I cite the case of an asthmatic chap in Sydney who went to the outpatients department of a hospital, gasping so much for air that he just handed them his Medicare card and asked for treatment. When the hospital tapped the computer for his file it revealed that he had a criminal record because he had received treatment while he was in prison. I can imagine other such cases involving details of requests to the Government for permission to prescribe some drugs. For example, doctors have to get permission from the Government if they want to prescribe under the national health system expensive drugs such as Zovirax, which is used for genital herpes. All that will be recorded on the database too. In other words, traditional confidentiality between doctor and patient will be pretty well lost.

There are lots of things that one may not want people to know but they will be on one's records. For example, one may have had a miscarriage, had a divorce, failed an exam, been sacked from somewhere, seen a psychiatrist or committed a traffic offence-any of those things. Let us suppose that someone is the authorised signing officer for a corgi dog club, for the local branch of the Australian Labor Party, or the National Party of Australia for that matter, or any of the little clubs in town. As the authorised signing officer, will he have to give his Australia Card number for that purpose because financial transactions are involved? If he is the newly elected secretary, he may have to make a first transaction. All of a sudden the bureaucrats will know that he is the secretary of the local branch of, say, the National Party. He may not want people to know that he is the secretary of the local branch of the National Party-or secretary of the local branch of the Labor Party, or whatever.

The important point I want to make there is that I would not want anyone to think that the Data Protection Agency will in any way protect our privacy. I also would not want anyone to think that the government does not intend to use its information and to get control of the people by harassing them. As I have mentioned, the Government has already shown its colours. Once we are recorded on all these databanks the Government can target any one person or group of persons. If it wants to attack architects, engineers, dentists or doctors, it can. I have mentioned the Greek conspiracy case in Sydney, which was a blatant misuse of the Health Insurance Commission's information.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was your government.

—Any government does it. The bureaucracy does it. Any government will do it. I have not specifically accused the Labor Government of doing it. The Government can target groups in the community. In the Greek conspiracy case the doctors had to defend themselves in court. They were all found innocent. It was very expensive for them. The Government did not even apologise to them.
—I am advised that Senator Chaney was the Minister at the time of the Greek conspiracy case. Is that correct?
—I referred merely to government.
—You are really talking about this Big Brother Government here now, aren't you?

—Yes, it is the Government I am mainly talking about. It is the Government which is bringing in the Australia Card. All it will do will be to facilitate the same sort of harassment. As I said, our soldiers have fought and died for the principle that we are innocent until we are proven guilty. The Australia Card is a mechanism to reverse that principle.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government is not going to use the Australia Card as a method of control by harassment, why is it forcing this card on the people in the face of mounting opposition to it? We have seen the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) do an about turn when issues were losing him public popularity and support. This issue is having exactly the same effect but he is not turning around.

The Government is claiming that the introduction of the Australia Card will vastly reduce tax fraud, social security fraud, immigration fraud and organised crime. I do not think that it will do so. Is the Government going to issue identity cards to companies? I imagine that the big tax losses in Australia have been due to company manipulations. But companies will not be involved in the Australia Card. However, I notice that the Commissioner of Taxation is putting auditors into companies now, which he thinks is doing a bit of good. It is only the people who will be harassed. The Government is not fixing the real problem, which is the high rates of tax.

Once again, I am reminded of a bit of Roman history. There was a pax romana which lasted for 500 years-the roman peace. The Romans were the top dogs in all of Europe. They sent tax collectors out amongst the community. If the tax collector collected too much tax the taxpayer was entitled to kill him. So the tax collectors never collected too much tax. There was enormous happiness and peace in the empire and the Romans ran the place for 500 years. The whole thing collapsed only when the Romans tried to collect too much tax. The Government's basic problem is that it is overtaxing the people, so they are trying to dodge tax altogether.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no incentive in their tax system, is there?

—None at all. The Australia Card is not going to fix the cash economy, and that is the main thing the Government is trying to do-fix tax fraud. The card will not fix welfare fraud. The problem is not one of identity. It involves changes of status and other things. We have had careful investigations by well-qualified committees and departments, all of which say that, not only will the card not do the things it is supposed to do, but also it is likely to exacerbate the problems. It may even start a big crime business, both inside and outside Australia, in the manufacture of false cards. It may create a black market in cards which has occurred in all countries that have the card.
—It hasn't.
—It certainly has. One can buy cards to get into America in Tijuana at quite reasonable rates. There is competition there.
—Who wants to go there?
—About two million people a year want to go to the US.
—For what?
—None Irish, I think. They are not that clever.
—They are all wanting to go to the wet tropics we are saving.
—Order! Honourable senators interjecting can make speeches later if they wish to.

—I oppose the Australia Card, and the National Party opposes it, because not only is it a bad thing in itself but also it has already caused enough trouble to the Australian people. It was the reason why we had the double dissolution and have now been inflicted with three more years of Labor government. I consider that punishment enough.

SPEECH.PARA: The card hardly rated as an issue during the election campaign, but it was not for want of trying. It was largely ignored by the media. I raised the issue in every speech I made. I issued endless streams of Press releases about it but they were all studiously ignored. Opposition senator after Opposition senator got up and made the same bleat and the same complaint. The issue is a prime example of the media taking the freedom of the Press as licence without responsibility. We all know that the more freedom one gets the more responsibility one has to exercise. And not only that, but the more freedom one has the harder one has to fight to keep it. That is what the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are doing for Australia now-fighting for the freedom of the Australian people.

The Australia Card represents the greatest threat to our freedom since the world wars. People have to be made to realise that. It represents enslavement, a fact which was mentioned in the chamber tonight. It is enslavement and control. It represents harassment and the invasion of privacy. It is a reversion of our common law to civil law. The Government expects us to pay for it. The enormous cost of the introduction of the card has also been mentioned tonight. I deplore the Bill. I support Senator Puplick's amendment to it. I will be very happy when we can forget the Australia Card.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —About the only thing that is left to say about the Australia Card Bill 1986 to those who are listening to this debate is that it has gone on for quite some time. It has been going on for two years since it was introduced. It is interesting to note that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is starting to find that the Australian people have woken up to what this Bill is all about. They are now having their voices heard in the Parliament of Australia. The Prime Minister's office is now receiving some 21 bags of mail per day, whereas it received only six bags of mail per day some time ago. That was before people became so concerned about this pernicious legislation which the Labor Party is trying to foist on the Australian people. The Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson), who is at the table, with his interest in the environment would be aware of the number of trees that are being cut down to produce the paper used for the protests about the legislation the Government is trying to foist on us.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not the first time the legislation has been debated at length. The National Party and the Liberal Party in particular have spoken out against it on many occasions. We have not had any satisfactory replies from the Government on the issue. The Australian Democrats will join us at this stage to make sure that the Bill is scrutinised. It will probably be even more frightening to the Australian people by the time the scrutiny is finished.

Many people on the Government benches are just as worried about the Australia Card as those on this side of the chamber. Senator Georges, our former colleague in this place, had the guts and the determination to speak up for what he believed in, and he suffered the supreme sacrifice as an Australian Labor Party member and ended his term in this Parliament as an independent. He was one of the people on the Labor Party side who definitely spoke out against the card, but there are a lot of others on the Government side who are thinking about it. It will be interesting to see what happens when the vote is taken. What will they do when we vote on this Bill? Will they vote according to their conscience, the way that their heart feels and their constituents think?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Of course they will not, Senator Short. They will not have the guts that Senator Georges had to speak and vote against it. They will probably go to the wire and push this Bill on to the Australian people. The only people who will save Australians from this Bill are those in the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators opposite can argue all they like that the card will make Australia a better place, but Australian citizens will have to prove that they are citizens by producing a piece of plastic. I think that is the most retrograde step that this country has ever taken. Under this draconian legislation, if a card is lost and that loss is not reported there is a $500 fine. If an employer when employing someone fails to sight the card, he can be up for a $20,000 fine. What if somebody hires a cardless person? That could easily happen. If that happens the employer can be fined $20,000. The penalty for destroying or defacing a card is imprisonment for two years or a $5,000 fine, or both. They are just a few of the penalties in the draconian legislation that can be imposed if a card is lost or destroyed. The legislation is quite clear on these penalties. They are spelt out in the legislation that the Government is trying to foist on to the Australian people. All the reasons that the Government has given for the necessity for the introduction of this card are spurious when we take into account the problems that it will cause the Australian people.

I cite the experience of West Germany, which has an ID card system, and it should be enough to terrify the most disinterested Australian voter. In the mid-1970s in West Germany a new wave of student protests panicked the Government of the day into making greater use of its surveillance and identification system. The system was used for surveillance of suspected terrorists, people presumed to be sympathisers and anyone else who happened to be in the wrong place at the right time. Spearheading the new form of police investigation was the President of the police, who set up a profile of what a terrorist would look like.

That is no different from the system that the Government is trying to set up in Australia. The description was established as someone between 25 and 35 years of age who lived in a high rise apartment and had a rented car. Following a terrorist or related incident the police were asked to look for people fitting such a description. Since this surveillance system was wide open to interpretation by the police as to who would be caught in this net, the profile of a typical terrorist expanded to anyone who bought lots of newspapers, who lived in a commune, who paid cash for his electricity, who wore a certain type of glasses, who paid his rent in cash, who used transit lanes to Berlin, who met members of parliament in Bonn, who moved frequently, who covered his face during demonstrations, who had a car with an anti-nuclear sticker and who patronised leftist pubs. The list was virtually endless, and thousands were caught up in this surveillance net. At one stage the computer had 11,000 terrorists registered-do not forget that we are going on to a computer-which even surprised the West German police. To increase the accuracy of the information and surveillance--

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk about the Bill instead of your fantasies.
—I think it is very necessary that the Australian people have an opportunity of knowing what the Bill is all about. That is why we are debating it.
—That is not what it is going to be about.

—This is what it is going to be about. This is the sort of thing that could happen here, in our Australia; the Australia that we thought we were citizens of. We did not think we would have to own a piece of plastic card to prove that we were citizens of this country. Surely that is a good enough answer for the honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: To increase the accuracy of the information and surveillance, the West German police even introduced a video camera with a microphone, which was placed near the residences of important politicians-of which the honourable senator would not be one-and generals and at railway stations. In this camera surveillance, licence plates of frequently passing cars were noted and persons passing these spots were often followed. Police surveillance and misuse of the national identification card system became so widespread that it became a farce. Senator Sheil has already mentioned that identification cards can be bought and the system can be abused. Yet people in West Germany lost their jobs and were no longer allowed to practise their professions, simply because they were unfortunate enough to be caught on the state-run identification card system. Surely the card introduced in Australia could cause the same problems which were caused in West Germany.

TALK.START.PARA: —How? Tell us.

—I thank the honourable senator for his indulgence in listening to that little story. It is not a bed time story but a story of something that actually happened in another country that had an identity card system.
—Not the same as this one.

—The Government has to prove that that will not happen to the Australian people. I think the effect of the card will be the same. There will probably be even bigger problems than those faced by West Germany.
—Rubbish!
—The honourable senator can call it rubbish if he likes. He should go out and tell the Australian people that it is rubbish. It is something that the Government is trying to foist on us.
—You were not game to do that during the campaign.

—The Prime Minister said that he would call an election because of the rejection of the Australia card. How often did the Prime Minister mention it during the election campaign? He did not mention it at all apart from one line in his election speech.
—It is like talking to a brick wall.
—Is the honourable member saying that talking to the Australian people is like talking to a brick wall?
—No, you lot; you dozy lot.

—The honourable senator has just said that when the Prime Minister spoke to the Australian people it was like speaking to a brick wall. He should go back to the Northern Territory and tell the people that. I think that the citizens of Australia deserve a better deal than having the Australia Card foisted on them. The Government wants to put Australia into a police state situation. We cannot ignore the experiences of other countries. The Government keeps on saying that the ID card system is being introduced to stop the tax cheats and the social security frauds. Why does the Taxation Office not admit that the card will not stop them? Have honourable senators read what the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card says that this card will do? Do they know why the Joint Select Committee came down with a majority report against the card? The Government has introduced so much legislation that has not been thought out fully. It introduced legislation on the fringe benefits tax which Government senators, except for Senator Collins from the Northern Territory, told us would not have any effect on the motor car industry. But what has happened to the motor car industry? Is it thriving? Of course it is not.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask a few more questions about the Australia Card. What will happen, for example, if a woman has two names, one business and one family? We have many instances of that in this Parliament. The wife of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) has a different name from that of her husband. Many other wives in the community have different names from those of their husbands. It is not uncommon for married partners to have different names.
