What happens if a business person, Ms X, opens a bank account in that name and has a credit card in her family name, Mrs Y. Does she get two ID cards? Does she in fact become a non-person?

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish you would.
—I thought he already was.
—God love us, the senator from Western Australia has come back into the chamber. Will the Government force that lady to choose and use one name?

SPEECH.PARA: What happens in the case of an overseas visitor who obtains a permit to work in Australia? Will such a person also have to obtain an ID card and, if he does, what happens when he leaves Australia? How will we know if he has left? The Government tells us that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs will not have any access to the ID data bank. So how will the Government know that a person has left the country? I presume that later in the debate Senator Ryan will be able to tell us how that will happen. What is to stop the card being passed on to a person coming into the country? That is what happens with social security cards in the United States of America, as my very good colleague Senator Sheil mentioned earlier in the debate. I am asking senators on the Government side why that will not happen here.

The Government says that we will not be able to do any business without the production of the card. Therefore, it is only reasonable to assume that banks and other financial institutions will establish files based on ID card numbers and other information. The databank will supposedly be hacker-proof. Of course, the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, Mr Duncan, Senator Ryan and the Prime Minister all have different ideas about whether the card will be hacker-proof and whether the data bank will not be hacker-proof. I am asking what protection there will be in respect of information of a similar nature which will be filed by the banks and other people. Again, Senator Sheil told us earlier tonight how the databank can have information stacked in it. He said that if people got access to this information they would know more about individuals than most probably wives or husbands know about each other. We read just about every day about data systems being breached by computer hackers. This is happening both here and abroad. One of the most recent examples of this was the hacker who got into the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation computer system.

Can the Government really convince us that the Australia Card databank is safe from such abuse? Can it guarantee the Australian people that this card is going to be safe and that all the files that will be kept on it will be kept secret? Can the Government guarantee to the Australian people that all of the databank material will be secure? We must bear in mind that that has not proved to be the case in other systems in Australia and elsewhere.

I wish to quote from one of the many letters that have been written by Australian people about the card. One of the letters was written by Peter Allenbone, of Rylstone, New South Wales, who, like some 60-odd per cent of the Australian people, is very concerned about the card. In part, he said:

. . . social welfare fraud is less than half of one pc (of expenditure) and that bureaucratic inefficiency resulting in overpayment of welfare cheques is the greatest source of loss in the welfare area.
The Government has not mentioned that matter. Mr Moore of Inverell says in his letter:
I cannot support the myth that our existing data banks are not already being cross referenced.
Can this Government guarantee the people of Australia that the databanks are not being cross-referenced? Mr Moore went on to say:
There will be no privacy. It will be prone to much abuse. This already happens. Why add to the problem?

The Act is to be administered by the bureaucratic authority but is to be policed by the `Data Protection Agency'. This `Agency' has unlimited powers and will have an appointed advisory committee. This committee has no representatives from either employers or primary production industries.
This `Agency' has unfettered powers without any accountability.

That is what this Government is doing. Without any accountability, it is trying to foist this card on to the Australian people. Surely this is the most draconian piece of legislation that this country has ever had to face. I am sure that the Australian Democrats will support the Liberal Party and the National Party in making sure that this Bill does not affect the Australian people in the way it surely would if it were passed in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating again the Australia Card Bill 1986, which we clearly oppose.
—You are one of the people who had good reason to oppose it probably.

—It seems that the Government is going to insist on pressing forward and thus ensuring that the legislation is defeated on this occasion and then on submitting it to a joint sitting of both Houses to have it passed. One might well ask why it is that the Opposition parties oppose the Australia Card and why it is that there is a growing army of people within our society who totally oppose it-people as diverse, and with as diverse backgrounds, as Peter Garrett from the rock band Midnight Oil, Sir Noel Foley, the past Chairman of the Westpac Banking Corporation, Mr Justice Michael Kirby, a former Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission who was subsequently appointed by the New South Wales Labor Government as President of the New South Wales Court of Appeal, the Victorian Society of Labor Lawyers, former royal commissioner Frank Costigan, the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, civil liberty groups right around Australia and Dr Shepherd, the President of the Australian Medical Association.

SPEECH.PARA: I note Senator Walsh's earlier interjection. Is this opposition to be explained away by Senator Ryan's pathetic cheap suggestion that anyone who opposes the identity card is a friend of a tax cheat or a social welfare cheat? Is she saying that of the Labor lawyers, of Mr Justice Kirby, of Peter Garrett or of the Catholic Social Welfare Commission? Of course she is not. It is just so easy to link these people with tax and welfare cheats in order to create hysteria within the community. It is as dishonest as most things the Government says in this chamber. The reason these people oppose the card is that the card will not achieve its aims, the amount of data the Government is able to collect and readily access about all the citizens in this country will grow, and there are alternatives which will achieve the same objectives of combating tax and welfare fraud which do not carry the same threats and dangers to the Australian way of life.

I shall describe briefly the proposal itself to indicate how wide ranging it is and how it could result in the recording of an ready access to intimate details of people's lives. The legislation before the Senate aimed at implementing the identity card will establish a national register of information such as names, addresses, date of birth, changes of name, employment status, changes of address and date of entry into Australia and entry permit data for people who are not Australian citizens. The unique number given to every person in the country will be recorded against this file of information. The same number will appear on the person's identity card along with that person's name and the expiry date of the card. In the case of minors age will be shown, and in the case of aliens employment details and eligibility for Medicare will be shown. Although the Government had tried to deceive the public into believing that the card will be optional and that no one need apply, as has been put to us in the Senate on a number of occasions by Senator Ryan in response to questions, it will be quite impossible to live, to earn, to save, to spend and to buy in this community--

TALK.START.PARA: —To cheat.
—Yes, it will be possible to cheat with the card.
—Harder.

—With respect, Senator Collins, you are wrong. It will certainly be impossible to live without the card. Should a person choose not to apply for a card he will be unable to receive a medical benefit or a social security payment; he will be unable to engage in land, shares, futures or foreign currency transactions. That person will be unable to withdraw his own money from his bank account and he will be unable to cash a cheque or have access to a safety deposit box. A farmer will be unable to receive payment from a primary produce marketing authority or a produce agent. Landlords of houses will not be able to receive rent from real estate agents acting in respect of their houses. In each case these activities will be banned unless the person has provided the other party with his identification number.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier Senator Beahan sought to be persuasive in his argument that the Government had a mandate to introduce this legislation and to have it passed. That is quite untrue. The general thrust of his argument was that because the Australian Labor Party gained the majority of seats in the House of Representatives that gave it a mandate. That is absurd, superficial logic. The Victorian Society of Labor Lawyers, for instance, I assume would have probably voted Labor in the last election. Yet those lawyers have made it clear they are totally opposed to the card and that if a referendum were put they would vote against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Barrie Unsworth.

—Yes, of course, the Premier of New South Wales. Finally, the Government conceals the fact that for the House of Representatives, on first preferences, 52.12 per cent of the people voted for parties opposing the card-the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia, the Country Liberal Party, the Australian Democrats and the Independents-and 45.78 per cent voted for the Australian Labor Party. If Government senators seek to argue on the basis of mandate they must accept that the majority of people voted against the card at the last election. If they are arguing that the card was an issue and that they won the election they must admit that. It is a contortion of logic not to do so. I am simply putting to rest the absurd argument that was put by a Labor senator earlier. If Government senators believe they have a mandate and they believe that the majority of people support the card, they should put the matter to a referendum. They should put the matter in splendid isolation so they can see whether the majority of people support the legislation.
—We have just had the referendum.

—Oh, so you have just had the referendum! Will Government senators then concede that the majority of people voted against the card? The majority of people voted for parties that opposed the card. If that was a referendum, why is the Government still pursuing the card?
—Order! There are too many interjections. I ask Senator Crichton-Browne to address his remarks through the Chair.

—Perhaps we could now turn to the taxation claim. Senator Walsh loves to tell us about the taxation cheats. At the very best, the ID card could be effective only against false names. As former royal commissioner Frank Costigan has said, there is no reason to assume that the bulk of taxation evasion can simply be attributed to fraudulent identity. There was a time when Mr Costigan was very respectable in the eyes of the Australian Labor Party. There was a time when Labor members use to quote him ad nauseam day after day.
—He certainly flushed out a few crooks in your Party.

—Senator Walsh keeps saying those sorts of things but even as he says that I am reminded that he is the only Minister that I can remember in the history of the Senate who has been censured by the majority of senators because he deceived the Senate. He failed to table a cheque with Lionel Murphy's name on it. He knew that the cheques were false, the Australian Federal Police have since proved they were false and Senator Walsh got nailed to the floor. Even his own colleagues--
— Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, could I ask you once again to address your remarks through the Chair?

—Yes, you certainly could. Let me remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the vast majority of Senator Walsh's colleagues were ashamed of him and embarrassed by him and they came and apologised to me for his conduct. In the last 24 hours they have been ashamed of him again, embarrassed by him and humiliated by him; they have attacked him, not the least of them being the Prime Minister of this country, Mr Hawke, who dragged him into his room by the scruff of his neck, gave him a smack around the ears and sent him out looking contrite and embarrassed. He misled his own Prime Minister yesterday. He said it was anecdotal evidence of two years ago. On the front page of today's Australian we find that he misled the Prime Minister. He has misled the Senate and he now is trying to mislead the whole community. If I were Senator Walsh I would not be too proud of my record. He is all talk.
—What about the insider trading you did in those Poseidon shares?
— Order! There are too many interjections. Could we please proceed with some decorum.
—He made a lot of money out of them.

—Eat your heart out! The truth of the matter is that the identity card cannot touch cash out of the till transactions. That is the most obvious example. That is the real problem we face at present with respect to tax evasion through lack of disclosure. I make the point that that is not a question of lack of disclosure of identity. In Italy, which has an identity card system, black money is guesstimated at approximately 30 per cent of gross product. That is a country where the ID card operates, yet the black market flourishes. There is no guarantee that the system can stop false identities and it is not intended to do so. In fact it is likely to institutionalise, legitimise and legalise them. That is one of the reasons that Costigan, QC, is totally opposed to the ID card system.
—Tell us how.
—It is very simple. It is not beyond the wit of top quality criminals to duplicate cards and legitimise their business by being able to open bank accounts and flourish in the normal commercial sense.
—There was no evidence given to that effect to the Joint Select Committee.

—I think that the honourable senator will find that Mr Costigan made that point in a compelling way. The Government says that it needs an ID card because it cannot rely on drivers licences, birth certificates and the information that is presently used, and yet it is from precisely these documents-low integrity documents as they are described-that it will compile the identity card database.
—Ask Senator Aulich about the in camera evidence before you speak, Senator Collins.
—I can only work on the public documents.

—I know the honourable senator can. What he ought to do is inquire further and not carry on superficially like flotsam and jetsam, on the wave of emotion that the Labor Party has whipped up for him. The ID card system will have all existing errors transplanted to it. To the extent that one can create forgery of birth certificates and wedding certificates, there will be a transfer of incorrect and improper information on to the ID card.

SPEECH.PARA: To appreciate the magnitude of potential errors, it should be remembered that it was Roger Clarke from the Australian National University Department of Information Systems and Chairman of the Economic, Legal and Social Implications Committee of the Australian Computer Society who said that it is quite common knowledge that 15,800,000 Medicare cards are on issue in Australia. Yet the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates that that we have a population of only 15,200,000 people. In other words, a great many more cards are circulating in society than there are bodies. Clearly there are duplications and forgeries.

Let me turn to the subject of immigrants. More than 20 per cent of people in this country were born overseas. How does a Vietnamese refugee obtain a birth certificate or, more to the point, how does an Australian official know that the document such a person presents is genuine? When he goes for his ID card, he can make up any name he likes. He climbs off a ship or boat and can have four or five names. One of the real problems in our society is that a small group of people, and I emphasise that it is a small group, are able to duplicate names, are able to claim not to be married, and are able to claim unemployment benefit-their wives are able to claim single mothers' supporting benefits-while at the same time they are working in the black economy. This is happening simply because there is no integrity in their birth certificates. It seems to me that, because of the anonymity afforded by an ID card, it will be very easy for cards to be forged and for them to obtain a market value. I believe that a forgery industry will spring up very quickly. The United States social security department estimates that between four million and five million Americans hold more than one social security number. It is assumed that the vast majority of those result from forgeries.

The greatest nonsense is contained in the Bill itself. To try to avoid forcing residents of a place such as the Pilbara, or the Kimberleys in Western Australia to climb aboard an aircraft to fly to Perth, in a round trip of several thousand miles, at enormous cost simply to open an account and to identify themselves with their card with their stockbroker, stock agent or real estate agent in the event that they want to buy a block of land in Bunbury or in the south-west of Western Australia, the Government has chosen to include in clause 36 of the Bill provision for certain `prescribed persons' such as lawyers, justices of the peace and those presently entitled to witness passport applications to sign a certificate saying that they have seen a person's identity card, have recorded its number and have sent it where it is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't even get any Labor lawyers to do that.

—I would say to Senator Walters that it would be open to massive abuse. Who in a stockbroker's firm in Perth or the land title office is to say that the information in the certificate is correct? Who is to say that the cardholder, the number and the witness are not all made up, or that perhaps the name and number of an innocent third party have not been used? They may have been used without that third party knowing about it. One can only imagine what will happen if the fraud is successful and if subsequently it comes to light in terms of income. How does an innocent third party explain the existence of that income to the Commissioner of Taxation, if all the statistics and evidence show that it was revenue earned in that year in his name and that a bank account had been opened accordingly? I suspect it is for just these reasons that the Department of Social Security has indicated that it will not accept the identity card alone as sufficient proof of identity. It judges its integrity to be such that it does not accept it at face value to identify the holder of the card.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, while we are discussing social security fraud it is important to remember that the Department of Social Security does not expect to make any savings through the use of the card because less than one per cent of forgeries on the department occur through the use of false identities. In fact the figure, as I recall it, given to the Committee was that 0.6 per cent of all social security frauds, and no more, occurred as a result of false identification. The vast majority of fraud was due to change of circumstances by the recipients and lack of notification of the Department or simply clerical errors by the Department. The Department also said that the added administrative costs will absorb any financial benefit it might have obtained. Even in the modest number of cases where there is false identification, the introduction of the identity card has nothing to offer because the Department already has the legislative power to cross-check its forms and receive information from the Australian Taxation Office.
Debate interrupted.
